fields.doc: Receive FIFO Not Empty. This bit is set when the receive FIFO contains one or more entries; it is cleared when the receive FIFO is empty. - 0: Receive FIFO is empty - 1: Receive FIFO is not empty Reset value: 0x0

fields.name: tfe
fields.doc: Transmit FIFO Completely Empty. When the transmit FIFO is completely empty, this bit is set. When it contains one or more valid entries, this bit is cleared. This bit field does not request an interrupt. - 0: Transmit FIFO is not empty - 1: Transmit FIFO is empty Reset value: 0x1

fields.name: tfnf
fields.doc: Transmit FIFO Not Full. Set when the transmit FIFO contains one or more empty locations, and is cleared when the FIFO is full. - 0: Transmit FIFO is full - 1: Transmit FIFO is not full Reset value: 0x1

i2c0.ic_status.name: ic_status
i2c0.ic_status.doc:
I2C Status Register


            This is a read-only register used to indicate the current transfer status and FIFO status. The status register may be read at any time. None of the bits in this register request an interrupt.


            When the I2C is disabled by writing 0 in bit 0 of the IC_ENABLE register: - Bits 1 and 2 are set to 1 - Bits 3 and 10 are set to 0 When the master or slave state machines goes to idle and ic_en=0: - Bits 5 and 6 are set to 0

fields.name: txflr
fields.doc:
Transmit FIFO Level. Contains the number of valid data entries in the transmit FIFO.\n\n
                Reset value: 0x0

i2c0.ic_txflr.name: ic_txflr
i2c0.ic_txflr.doc: I2C Transmit FIFO Level Register This register contains the number of valid data entries in the transmit FIFO buffer. It is cleared whenever: - The I2C is disabled - There is a transmit abort - that is, TX_ABRT bit is set in the IC_RAW_INTR_STAT register - The slave bulk transmit mode is aborted The register increments whenever data is placed into the transmit FIFO and decrements when data is taken from the transmit FIFO.

fields.name: rxflr
fields.doc:
Receive FIFO Level. Contains the number of valid data entries in the receive FIFO.\n\n
                Reset value: 0x0

i2c0.ic_rxflr.name: ic_rxflr
i2c0.ic_rxflr.doc: I2C Receive FIFO Level Register This register contains the number of valid data entries in the receive FIFO buffer. It is cleared whenever: - The I2C is disabled - Whenever there is a transmit abort caused by any of the events tracked in IC_TX_ABRT_SOURCE The register increments whenever data is placed into the receive FIFO and decrements when data is taken from the receive FIFO.

fields.name: ic_sda_rx_hold
fields.doc:
Sets the required SDA hold time in units of ic_clk period, when DW_apb_i2c acts as a receiver.\n\n
                Reset value: IC_DEFAULT_SDA_HOLD[23:16].

fields.name: ic_sda_tx_hold
fields.doc:
Sets the required SDA hold time in units of ic_clk period, when DW_apb_i2c acts as a transmitter.\n\n
                Reset value: IC_DEFAULT_SDA_HOLD[15:0].

i2c0.ic_sda_hold.name: ic_sda_hold
i2c0.ic_sda_hold.doc:
I2C SDA Hold Time Length Register


            The bits [15:0] of this register are used to control the hold time of SDA during transmit in both slave and master mode (after SCL goes from HIGH to LOW).


            The bits [23:16] of this register are used to extend the SDA transition (if any) whenever SCL is HIGH in the receiver in either master or slave mode.


            Writes to this register succeed only when IC_ENABLE[0]=0.


            The values in this register are in units of ic_clk period. The value programmed in IC_SDA_TX_HOLD must be greater than the minimum hold time in each mode one cycle in master mode, seven cycles in slave mode for the value to be implemented.


            The programmed SDA hold time during transmit (IC_SDA_TX_HOLD) cannot exceed at any time the duration of the low part of scl. Therefore the programmed value cannot be larger than N_SCL_LOW-2, where N_SCL_LOW is the duration of the low part of the scl period measured in ic_clk cycles.

fields.name: tx_flush_cnt
fields.doc:
This field indicates the number of Tx FIFO Data Commands which are flushed due to TX_ABRT interrupt. It is cleared whenever I2C is disabled.


                Reset value: 0x0


                Role of DW_apb_i2c:  Master-Transmitter or Slave-Transmitter

fields.name: abrt_user_abrt
fields.doc:
This is a master-mode-only bit. Master has detected the transfer abort (IC_ENABLE[1])


                Reset value: 0x0


                Role of DW_apb_i2c:  Master-Transmitter

fields.name: abrt_slvrd_intx
fields.doc:
1: When the processor side responds to a slave mode request for data to be transmitted to a remote master and user writes a 1 in CMD (bit 8) of IC_DATA_CMD register.


                Reset value: 0x0


                Role of DW_apb_i2c:  Slave-Transmitter

fields.name: abrt_slv_arblost
fields.doc:
This field indicates that a Slave has lost the bus while transmitting data to a remote master. IC_TX_ABRT_SOURCE[12] is set at the same time. Note:  Even though the slave never 'owns' the bus, something could go wrong on the bus. This is a fail safe check. For instance, during a data transmission at the low-to-high transition of SCL, if what is on the data bus is not what is supposed to be transmitted, then DW_apb_i2c no longer own the bus.


                Reset value: 0x0


                Role of DW_apb_i2c:  Slave-Transmitter

fields.name: abrt_slvflush_txfifo
fields.doc:
This field specifies that the Slave has received a read command and some data exists in the TX FIFO, so the slave issues a TX_ABRT interrupt to flush old data in TX FIFO.


                Reset value: 0x0


                Role of DW_apb_i2c:  Slave-Transmitter

fields.name: arb_lost
fields.doc:
This field specifies that the Master has lost arbitration, or if IC_TX_ABRT_SOURCE[14] is also set, then the slave transmitter has lost arbitration.


                Reset value: 0x0


                Role of DW_apb_i2c:  Master-Transmitter or Slave-Transmitter

fields.name: abrt_master_dis
fields.doc:
This field indicates that the User tries to initiate a Master operation with the Master mode disabled.


                Reset value: 0x0


                Role of DW_apb_i2c:  Master-Transmitter or Master-Receiver

fields.name: abrt_10b_rd_norstrt
fields.doc:
This field indicates that the restart is disabled (IC_RESTART_EN bit (IC_CON[5]) =0) and the master sends a read command in 10-bit addressing mode.


                Reset value: 0x0


                Role of DW_apb_i2c:  Master-Receiver

fields.name: abrt_sbyte_norstrt
fields.doc:
To clear Bit 9, the source of the ABRT_SBYTE_NORSTRT must be fixed first; restart must be enabled (IC_CON[5]=1), the SPECIAL bit must be cleared (IC_TAR[11]), or the GC_OR_START bit must be cleared (IC_TAR[10]). Once the source of the ABRT_SBYTE_NORSTRT is fixed, then this bit can be cleared in the same manner as other bits in this register. If the source of the ABRT_SBYTE_NORSTRT is not fixed before attempting to clear this bit, bit 9 clears for one cycle and then gets reasserted. When this field is set to 1, the restart is disabled (IC_RESTART_EN bit (IC_CON[5]) =0) and the user is trying to send a START Byte.


                Reset value: 0x0


                Role of DW_apb_i2c:  Master

fields.name: abrt_hs_norstrt
fields.doc:
This field indicates that the restart is disabled (IC_RESTART_EN bit (IC_CON[5]) =0) and the user is trying to use the master to transfer data in High Speed mode.


                Reset value: 0x0


                Role of DW_apb_i2c:  Master-Transmitter or Master-Receiver

fields.name: abrt_sbyte_ackdet
fields.doc:
This field indicates that the Master has sent a START Byte and the START Byte was acknowledged (wrong behavior).


                Reset value: 0x0


                Role of DW_apb_i2c:  Master

fields.name: abrt_hs_ackdet
fields.doc:
This field indicates that the Master is in High Speed mode and the High Speed Master code was acknowledged (wrong behavior).


                Reset value: 0x0


                Role of DW_apb_i2c:  Master

fields.name: abrt_gcall_read
fields.doc:
This field indicates that DW_apb_i2c in the master mode has sent a General Call but the user programmed the byte following the General Call to be a read from the bus (IC_DATA_CMD[9] is set to 1).


                Reset value: 0x0


                Role of DW_apb_i2c:  Master-Transmitter

fields.name: abrt_gcall_noack
fields.doc:
This field indicates that DW_apb_i2c in master mode has sent a General Call and no slave on the bus acknowledged the General Call.


                Reset value: 0x0


                Role of DW_apb_i2c:  Master-Transmitter

fields.name: abrt_txdata_noack
fields.doc:
This field indicates the master-mode only bit. When the master receives an acknowledgement for the address, but when it sends data byte(s) following the address, it did not receive an acknowledge from the remote slave(s).


                Reset value: 0x0


                Role of DW_apb_i2c:  Master-Transmitter

fields.name: abrt_10addr2_noack
fields.doc:
This field indicates that the Master is in 10-bit address mode and that the second address byte of the 10-bit address was not acknowledged by any slave.


                Reset value: 0x0


                Role of DW_apb_i2c:  Master-Transmitter or Master-Receiver

fields.name: abrt_10addr1_noack
fields.doc:
This field indicates that the Master is in 10-bit address mode and the first 10-bit address byte was not acknowledged by any slave.


                Reset value: 0x0


                Role of DW_apb_i2c:  Master-Transmitter or Master-Receiver

fields.name: abrt_7b_addr_noack
fields.doc:
This field indicates that the Master is in 7-bit addressing mode and the address sent was not acknowledged by any slave.


                Reset value: 0x0


                Role of DW_apb_i2c:  Master-Transmitter or Master-Receiver

i2c0.ic_tx_abrt_source.name: ic_tx_abrt_source
i2c0.ic_tx_abrt_source.doc:
I2C Transmit Abort Source Register


            This register has 32 bits that indicate the source of the TX_ABRT bit. Except for Bit 9, this register is cleared whenever the IC_CLR_TX_ABRT register or the IC_CLR_INTR register is read. To clear Bit 9, the source of the ABRT_SBYTE_NORSTRT must be fixed first; RESTART must be enabled (IC_CON[5]=1), the SPECIAL bit must be cleared (IC_TAR[11]), or the GC_OR_START bit must be cleared (IC_TAR[10]).


            Once the source of the ABRT_SBYTE_NORSTRT is fixed, then this bit can be cleared in the same manner as other bits in this register. If the source of the ABRT_SBYTE_NORSTRT is not fixed before attempting to clear this bit, Bit 9 clears for one cycle and is then re-asserted.

fields.name: nack
fields.doc:
Generate NACK. This NACK generation only occurs when DW_apb_i2c is a slave-receiver. If this register is set to a value of 1, it can only generate a NACK after a data byte is received; hence, the data transfer is aborted and the data received is not pushed to the receive buffer.\n\n
                When the register is set to a value of 0, it generates NACK/ACK, depending on normal criteria. - 1: generate NACK after data byte received - 0: generate NACK/ACK normally Reset value: 0x0

i2c0.ic_slv_data_nack_only.name: ic_slv_data_nack_only
i2c0.ic_slv_data_nack_only.doc:
Generate Slave Data NACK Register


            The register is used to generate a NACK for the data part of a transfer when DW_apb_i2c is acting as a slave-receiver. This register only exists when the IC_SLV_DATA_NACK_ONLY parameter is set to 1. When this parameter disabled, this register does not exist and writing to the register's address has no effect.


            A write can occur on this register if both of the following conditions are met: - DW_apb_i2c is disabled (IC_ENABLE[0] = 0) - Slave part is inactive (IC_STATUS[6] = 0) Note: The IC_STATUS[6] is a register read-back location for the internal slv_activity signal; the user should poll this before writing the ic_slv_data_nack_only bit.

fields.name: tdmae
fields.doc: Transmit DMA Enable. This bit enables/disables the transmit FIFO DMA channel. Reset value: 0x0

fields.name: rdmae
fields.doc: Receive DMA Enable. This bit enables/disables the receive FIFO DMA channel. Reset value: 0x0

i2c0.ic_dma_cr.name: ic_dma_cr
i2c0.ic_dma_cr.doc:
DMA Control Register\n\n
            The register is used to enable the DMA Controller interface operation. There is a separate bit for transmit and receive. This can be programmed regardless of the state of IC_ENABLE.

fields.name: dmatdl
fields.doc:
Transmit Data Level. This bit field controls the level at which a DMA request is made by the transmit logic. It is equal to the watermark level; that is, the dma_tx_req signal is generated when the number of valid data entries in the transmit FIFO is equal to or below this field value, and TDMAE = 1.\n\n
                Reset value: 0x0

fields.name: dmardl
fields.doc:
Receive Data Level. This bit field controls the level at which a DMA request is made by the receive logic. The watermark level = DMARDL+1; that is, dma_rx_req is generated when the number of valid data entries in the receive FIFO is equal to or more than this field value + 1, and RDMAE =1. For instance, when DMARDL is 0, then dma_rx_req is asserted when 1 or more data entries are present in the receive FIFO.\n\n
                Reset value: 0x0

fields.name: sda_setup
fields.doc: SDA Setup. It is recommended that if the required delay is 1000ns, then for an ic_clk frequency of 10 MHz, IC_SDA_SETUP should be programmed to a value of 11. IC_SDA_SETUP must be programmed with a minimum value of 2.

i2c0.ic_sda_setup.name: ic_sda_setup
i2c0.ic_sda_setup.doc:
I2C SDA Setup Register


            This register controls the amount of time delay (in terms of number of ic_clk clock periods) introduced in the rising edge of SCL - relative to SDA changing - when DW_apb_i2c services a read request in a slave-transmitter operation. The relevant I2C requirement is tSU:DAT (note 4) as detailed in the I2C Bus Specification. This register must be programmed with a value equal to or greater than 2.


            Writes to this register succeed only when IC_ENABLE[0] = 0.


            Note: The length of setup time is calculated using [(IC_SDA_SETUP - 1) * (ic_clk_period)], so if the user requires 10 ic_clk periods of setup time, they should program a value of 11. The IC_SDA_SETUP register is only used by the DW_apb_i2c when operating as a slave transmitter.

fields.name: ack_gen_call
fields.doc: ACK General Call. When set to 1, DW_apb_i2c responds with a ACK (by asserting ic_data_oe) when it receives a General Call. Otherwise, DW_apb_i2c responds with a NACK (by negating ic_data_oe).

i2c0.ic_ack_general_call.name: ic_ack_general_call
i2c0.ic_ack_general_call.doc:
I2C ACK General Call Register


            The register controls whether DW_apb_i2c responds with a ACK or NACK when it receives an I2C General Call address.


            This register is applicable only when the DW_apb_i2c is in slave mode.

fields.name: slv_rx_data_lost
fields.doc:
Slave Received Data Lost. This bit indicates if a Slave-Receiver operation has been aborted with at least one data byte received from an I2C transfer due to the setting bit 0 of IC_ENABLE from 1 to 0. When read as 1, DW_apb_i2c is deemed to have been actively engaged in an aborted I2C transfer (with matching address) and the data phase of the I2C transfer has been entered, even though a data byte has been responded with a NACK.


                Note:  If the remote I2C master terminates the transfer with a STOP condition before the DW_apb_i2c has a chance to NACK a transfer, and IC_ENABLE[0] has been set to 0, then this bit is also set to 1.


                When read as 0, DW_apb_i2c is deemed to have been disabled without being actively involved in the data phase of a Slave-Receiver transfer.


                Note:  The CPU can safely read this bit when IC_EN (bit 0) is read as 0.


                Reset value: 0x0

fields.name: slv_disabled_while_busy
fields.doc:
Slave Disabled While Busy (Transmit, Receive). This bit indicates if a potential or active Slave operation has been aborted due to the setting bit 0 of the IC_ENABLE register from 1 to 0. This bit is set when the CPU writes a 0 to the IC_ENABLE register while:


                (a) DW_apb_i2c is receiving the address byte of the Slave-Transmitter operation from a remote master;


                OR,


                (b) address and data bytes of the Slave-Receiver operation from a remote master.


                When read as 1, DW_apb_i2c is deemed to have forced a NACK during any part of an I2C transfer, irrespective of whether the I2C address matches the slave address set in DW_apb_i2c (IC_SAR register) OR if the transfer is completed before IC_ENABLE is set to 0 but has not taken effect.


                Note:  If the remote I2C master terminates the transfer with a STOP condition before the DW_apb_i2c has a chance to NACK a transfer, and IC_ENABLE[0] has been set to 0, then this bit will also be set to 1.


                When read as 0, DW_apb_i2c is deemed to have been disabled when there is master activity, or when the I2C bus is idle.


                Note:  The CPU can safely read this bit when IC_EN (bit 0) is read as 0.


                Reset value: 0x0

fields.name: ic_en
fields.doc:
ic_en Status. This bit always reflects the value driven on the output port ic_en. - When read as 1, DW_apb_i2c is deemed to be in an enabled state. - When read as 0, DW_apb_i2c is deemed completely inactive. Note:  The CPU can safely read this bit anytime. When this bit is read as 0, the CPU can safely read SLV_RX_DATA_LOST (bit 2) and SLV_DISABLED_WHILE_BUSY (bit 1).\n\n
                Reset value: 0x0

i2c0.ic_enable_status.name: ic_enable_status
i2c0.ic_enable_status.doc:
I2C Enable Status Register


            The register is used to report the DW_apb_i2c hardware status when the IC_ENABLE[0] register is set from 1 to 0; that is, when DW_apb_i2c is disabled.


            If IC_ENABLE[0] has been set to 1, bits 2:1 are forced to 0, and bit 0 is forced to 1.


            If IC_ENABLE[0] has been set to 0, bits 2:1 is only be valid as soon as bit 0 is read as '0'.


            Note: When IC_ENABLE[0] has been set to 0, a delay occurs for bit 0 to be read as 0 because disabling the DW_apb_i2c depends on I2C bus activities.

fields.name: ic_fs_spklen
fields.doc: This register must be set before any I2C bus transaction can take place to ensure stable operation. This register sets the duration, measured in ic_clk cycles, of the longest spike in the SCL or SDA lines that will be filtered out by the spike suppression logic. This register can be written only when the I2C interface is disabled which corresponds to the IC_ENABLE[0] register being set to 0. Writes at other times have no effect. The minimum valid value is 1; hardware prevents values less than this being written, and if attempted results in 1 being set. or more information, refer to 'Spike Suppression'.

i2c0.ic_fs_spklen.name: ic_fs_spklen
i2c0.ic_fs_spklen.doc:
I2C SS, FS or FM+ spike suppression limit\n\n
            This register is used to store the duration, measured in ic_clk cycles, of the longest spike that is filtered out by the spike suppression logic when the component is operating in SS, FS or FM+ modes. The relevant I2C requirement is tSP (table 4) as detailed in the I2C Bus Specification. This register must be programmed with a minimum value of 1.

fields.name: clr_restart_det
fields.doc:
Read this register to clear the RESTART_DET interrupt (bit 12) of IC_RAW_INTR_STAT register.\n\n
                Reset value: 0x0

fields.name: hc_count_values
fields.doc: Programmable count values for each mode.

fields.name: apb_data_width
fields.doc: APB data bus width is 32 bits

i2c0.ic_comp_param_1.name: ic_comp_param_1
i2c0.ic_comp_param_1.doc:
Component Parameter Register 1\n\n
            Note This register is not implemented and therefore reads as 0. If it was implemented it would be a constant read-only register that contains encoded information about the component's parameter settings. Fields shown below are the settings for those parameters

fields.name: ic_comp_type
fields.doc: Designware Component Type number = 0x44_57_01_40. This assigned unique hex value is constant and is derived from the two ASCII letters 'DW' followed by a 16-bit unsigned number.

adc.name: adc
adc.doc: Control and data interface to SAR ADC

fields.name: rrobin
fields.doc:
Round-robin sampling. 1 bit per channel. Set all bits to 0 to disable.\n
                Otherwise, the ADC will cycle through each enabled channel in a round-robin fashion.\n
                The first channel to be sampled will be the one currently indicated by AINSEL.\n
                AINSEL will be updated after each conversion with the newly-selected channel.

fields.name: ainsel
fields.doc: Select analog mux input. Updated automatically in round-robin mode.

fields.name: err_sticky
fields.doc: Some past ADC conversion encountered an error. Write 1 to clear.

fields.name: err
fields.doc: The most recent ADC conversion encountered an error; result is undefined or noisy.

fields.name: ready
fields.doc:
1 if the ADC is ready to start a new conversion. Implies any previous conversion has completed.\n
                0 whilst conversion in progress.

fields.name: start_many
fields.doc: Continuously perform conversions whilst this bit is 1. A new conversion will start immediately after the previous finishes.

fields.name: start_once
fields.doc: Start a single conversion. Self-clearing. Ignored if start_many is asserted.

fields.name: ts_en
fields.doc: Power on temperature sensor. 1 - enabled. 0 - disabled.

fields.name: en
fields.doc:
Power on ADC and enable its clock.\n
                1 - enabled. 0 - disabled.

adc.result.name: result
adc.result.doc: Result of most recent ADC conversion

fields.name: level
fields.doc: The number of conversion results currently waiting in the FIFO

fields.name: over
fields.doc: 1 if the FIFO has been overflowed. Write 1 to clear.

fields.name: under
fields.doc: 1 if the FIFO has been underflowed. Write 1 to clear.

fields.name: dreq_en
fields.doc: If 1: assert DMA requests when FIFO contains data

fields.name: err
fields.doc: If 1: conversion error bit appears in the FIFO alongside the result

fields.name: shift
fields.doc: If 1: FIFO results are right-shifted to be one byte in size. Enables DMA to byte buffers.

fields.name: en
fields.doc: If 1: write result to the FIFO after each conversion.

fields.name: err
fields.doc: 1 if this particular sample experienced a conversion error. Remains in the same location if the sample is shifted.

fields.name: frac
fields.doc: Fractional part of clock divisor. First-order delta-sigma.

adc.div.name: div
adc.div.doc:
Clock divider. If non-zero, CS_START_MANY will start conversions\n
            at regular intervals rather than back-to-back.\n
            The divider is reset when either of these fields are written.\n
            Total period is 1 + INT + FRAC / 256

fields.name: fifo
fields.doc:
Triggered when the sample FIFO reaches a certain level.\n
                This level can be programmed via the FCS_THRESH field.

fields.name: fifo
fields.doc:
Triggered when the sample FIFO reaches a certain level.\n
                This level can be programmed via the FCS_THRESH field.

fields.name: fifo
fields.doc:
Triggered when the sample FIFO reaches a certain level.\n
                This level can be programmed via the FCS_THRESH field.

fields.name: fifo
fields.doc:
Triggered when the sample FIFO reaches a certain level.\n
                This level can be programmed via the FCS_THRESH field.

fields.name: ph_adv
fields.doc:
Advance the phase of the counter by 1 count, while it is running.\n
                Self-clearing. Write a 1, and poll until low. Counter must be running\n
                at less than full speed (div_int + div_frac / 16 > 1)

fields.name: ph_ret
fields.doc:
Retard the phase of the counter by 1 count, while it is running.\n
                Self-clearing. Write a 1, and poll until low. Counter must be running.

pwm.ch0_div.name: ch0_div
pwm.ch0_div.doc:
INT and FRAC form a fixed-point fractional number.\n
            Counting rate is system clock frequency divided by this number.\n
            Fractional division uses simple 1st-order sigma-delta.

pwm.ch0_ctr.name: ch0_ctr
pwm.ch0_ctr.doc: Direct access to the PWM counter

fields.name: ph_adv
fields.doc:
Advance the phase of the counter by 1 count, while it is running.\n
                Self-clearing. Write a 1, and poll until low. Counter must be running\n
                at less than full speed (div_int + div_frac / 16 > 1)

fields.name: ph_ret
fields.doc:
Retard the phase of the counter by 1 count, while it is running.\n
                Self-clearing. Write a 1, and poll until low. Counter must be running.

pwm.ch1_div.name: ch1_div
pwm.ch1_div.doc:
INT and FRAC form a fixed-point fractional number.\n
            Counting rate is system clock frequency divided by this number.\n
            Fractional division uses simple 1st-order sigma-delta.

pwm.ch1_ctr.name: ch1_ctr
pwm.ch1_ctr.doc: Direct access to the PWM counter

pwm.ch7_ctr.doc: Direct access to the PWM counter

pwm.en.name: en
pwm.en.doc:
This register aliases the CSR_EN bits for all channels.\n
            Writing to this register allows multiple channels to be enabled\n
            or disabled simultaneously, so they can run in perfect sync.\n
            For each channel, there is only one physical EN register bit,\n
            which can be accessed through here or CHx_CSR.

timer.name: timer
timer.doc:
Controls time and alarms\n
        time is a 64 bit value indicating the time in usec since power-on\n
        timeh is the top 32 bits of time & timel is the bottom 32 bits\n
        to change time write to timelw before timehw\n
        to read time read from timelr before timehr\n
        An alarm is set by setting alarm_enable and writing to the corresponding alarm register\n
        When an alarm is pending, the corresponding alarm_running signal will be high\n
        An alarm can be cancelled before it has finished by clearing the alarm_enable\n
        When an alarm fires, the corresponding alarm_irq is set and alarm_running is cleared\n
        To clear the interrupt write a 1 to the corresponding alarm_irq

timer.timehw.name: timehw
timer.timehw.doc:
Write to bits 63:32 of time\n
            always write timelw before timehw

timer.timelw.name: timelw
timer.timelw.doc:
Write to bits 31:0 of time\n
            writes do not get copied to time until timehw is written

timer.timehr.name: timehr
timer.timehr.doc:
Read from bits 63:32 of time\n
            always read timelr before timehr

timer.alarm0.name: alarm0
timer.alarm0.doc:
Arm alarm 0, and configure the time it will fire.\n
            Once armed, the alarm fires when TIMER_ALARM0 == TIMELR.\n
            The alarm will disarm itself once it fires, and can\n
            be disarmed early using the ARMED status register.

timer.alarm1.name: alarm1
timer.alarm1.doc:
Arm alarm 1, and configure the time it will fire.\n
            Once armed, the alarm fires when TIMER_ALARM1 == TIMELR.\n
            The alarm will disarm itself once it fires, and can\n
            be disarmed early using the ARMED status register.

timer.alarm2.name: alarm2
timer.alarm2.doc:
Arm alarm 2, and configure the time it will fire.\n
            Once armed, the alarm fires when TIMER_ALARM2 == TIMELR.\n
            The alarm will disarm itself once it fires, and can\n
            be disarmed early using the ARMED status register.

timer.alarm3.name: alarm3
timer.alarm3.doc:
Arm alarm 3, and configure the time it will fire.\n
            Once armed, the alarm fires when TIMER_ALARM3 == TIMELR.\n
            The alarm will disarm itself once it fires, and can\n
            be disarmed early using the ARMED status register.

timer.armed.name: armed
timer.armed.doc:
Indicates the armed/disarmed status of each alarm.\n
            A write to the corresponding ALARMx register arms the alarm.\n
            Alarms automatically disarm upon firing, but writing ones here\n
            will disarm immediately without waiting to fire.

timer.timerawh.name: timerawh
timer.timerawh.doc: Raw read from bits 63:32 of time (no side effects)

timer.timerawl.name: timerawl
timer.timerawl.doc: Raw read from bits 31:0 of time (no side effects)

fields.name: dbg1
fields.doc: Pause when processor 1 is in debug mode

fields.name: dbg0
fields.doc: Pause when processor 0 is in debug mode

timer.dbgpause.name: dbgpause
timer.dbgpause.doc: Set bits high to enable pause when the corresponding debug ports are active

timer.pause.name: pause
timer.pause.doc: Set high to pause the timer

fields.name: enable
fields.doc: When not enabled the watchdog timer is paused

fields.name: pause_dbg1
fields.doc: Pause the watchdog timer when processor 1 is in debug mode

fields.name: pause_dbg0
fields.doc: Pause the watchdog timer when processor 0 is in debug mode

fields.name: pause_jtag
fields.doc: Pause the watchdog timer when JTAG is accessing the bus fabric

fields.name: time
fields.doc: Indicates the number of ticks / 2 (see errata RP2040-E1) before a watchdog reset will be triggered

watchdog.ctrl.name: ctrl
watchdog.ctrl.doc:
Watchdog control\n
            The rst_wdsel register determines which subsystems are reset when the watchdog is triggered.\n
            The watchdog can be triggered in software.

watchdog.load.name: load
watchdog.load.doc: Load the watchdog timer. The maximum setting is 0xffffff which corresponds to 0xffffff / 2 ticks before triggering a watchdog reset (see errata RP2040-E1).

watchdog.reason.name: reason
watchdog.reason.doc: Logs the reason for the last reset. Both bits are zero for the case of a hardware reset.

watchdog.scratch0.name: scratch0
watchdog.scratch0.doc: Scratch register. Information persists through soft reset of the chip.

watchdog.scratch1.name: scratch1
watchdog.scratch1.doc: Scratch register. Information persists through soft reset of the chip.

watchdog.scratch2.name: scratch2
watchdog.scratch2.doc: Scratch register. Information persists through soft reset of the chip.

watchdog.scratch3.name: scratch3
watchdog.scratch3.doc: Scratch register. Information persists through soft reset of the chip.

watchdog.scratch4.name: scratch4
watchdog.scratch4.doc: Scratch register. Information persists through soft reset of the chip.

watchdog.scratch5.name: scratch5
watchdog.scratch5.doc: Scratch register. Information persists through soft reset of the chip.

watchdog.scratch6.name: scratch6
watchdog.scratch6.doc: Scratch register. Information persists through soft reset of the chip.

watchdog.scratch7.name: scratch7
watchdog.scratch7.doc: Scratch register. Information persists through soft reset of the chip.

fields.name: count
fields.doc: Count down timer: the remaining number clk_tick cycles before the next tick is generated.

fields.name: cycles
fields.doc: Total number of clk_tick cycles before the next tick.

rtc.clkdiv_m1.name: clkdiv_m1
rtc.clkdiv_m1.doc: Divider minus 1 for the 1 second counter. Safe to change the value when RTC is not enabled.

fields.name: dotw
fields.doc: Day of the week: 1-Monday...0-Sunday ISO 8601 mod 7

fields.name: force_notleapyear
fields.doc:
If set, leapyear is forced off.\n
                Useful for years divisible by 100 but not by 400

fields.name: match_ena
fields.doc: Global match enable. Don't change any other value while this one is enabled

fields.name: dotw_ena
fields.doc: Enable day of the week matching

rtc.rtc_0.name: rtc_0
rtc.rtc_0.doc:
RTC register 0\n
            Read this before RTC 1!

fields.name: enable
fields.doc:
On power-up this field is initialised to ENABLE\n
                The system clock must be switched to another source before setting this field to DISABLE otherwise the chip will lock up\n
                The 12-bit code is intended to give some protection against accidental writes. An invalid setting will enable the oscillator.

fields.name: freq_range
fields.doc:
Controls the number of delay stages in the ROSC ring\n
                LOW uses stages 0 to 7\n
                MEDIUM uses stages 0 to 5\n
                HIGH uses stages 0 to 3\n
                TOOHIGH uses stages 0 to 1 and should not be used because its frequency exceeds design specifications\n
                The clock output will not glitch when changing the range up one step at a time\n
                The clock output will glitch when changing the range down\n
                Note: the values here are gray coded which is why HIGH comes before TOOHIGH

fields.name: passwd
fields.doc:
Set to 0x9696 to apply the settings\n
                Any other value in this field will set all drive strengths to 0

rosc.freqa.name: freqa
rosc.freqa.doc:
The FREQA & FREQB registers control the frequency by controlling the drive strength of each stage\n
            The drive strength has 4 levels determined by the number of bits set\n
            Increasing the number of bits set increases the drive strength and increases the oscillation frequency\n
            0 bits set is the default drive strength\n
            1 bit set doubles the drive strength\n
            2 bits set triples drive strength\n
            3 bits set quadruples drive strength

fields.name: passwd
fields.doc:
Set to 0x9696 to apply the settings\n
                Any other value in this field will set all drive strengths to 0

rosc.freqb.name: freqb
rosc.freqb.doc: For a detailed description see freqa register

rosc.dormant.name: dormant
rosc.dormant.doc:
Ring Oscillator pause control\n
            This is used to save power by pausing the ROSC\n
            On power-up this field is initialised to WAKE\n
            An invalid write will also select WAKE\n
            Warning: setup the irq before selecting dormant mode

fields.name: div
fields.doc:
set to 0xaa0 + div where\n
                div = 0 divides by 32\n
                div = 1-31 divides by div\n
                any other value sets div=0 and therefore divides by 32\n
                this register resets to div=16

fields.name: passwd
fields.doc:
set to 0xaa0\n
                any other value enables the output with shift=0

fields.name: enable
fields.doc:
enable the phase-shifted output\n
                this can be changed on-the-fly

fields.name: flip
fields.doc:
invert the phase-shifted output\n
                this is ignored when div=1

fields.name: shift
fields.doc:
phase shift the phase-shifted output by SHIFT input clocks\n
                this can be changed on-the-fly\n
                must be set to 0 before setting div=1

fields.name: badwrite
fields.doc: An invalid value has been written to CTRL_ENABLE or CTRL_FREQ_RANGE or FRFEQA or FREQB or DORMANT

fields.name: div_running
fields.doc:
post-divider is running\n
                this resets to 0 but transitions to 1 during chip startup

fields.name: enabled
fields.doc:
Oscillator is enabled but not necessarily running and stable\n
                this resets to 0 but transitions to 1 during chip startup

rosc.randombit.name: randombit
rosc.randombit.doc: This just reads the state of the oscillator output so randomness is compromised if the ring oscillator is stopped or run at a harmonic of the bus frequency

rosc.count.name: count
rosc.count.doc:
A down counter running at the ROSC frequency which counts to zero and stops.\n
            To start the counter write a non-zero value.\n
            Can be used for short software pauses when setting up time sensitive hardware.

vreg_and_chip_reset.name: vreg_and_chip_reset
vreg_and_chip_reset.doc: control and status for on-chip voltage regulator and chip level reset subsystem

fields.name: hiz
fields.doc:
high impedance mode select\n
                0=not in high impedance mode, 1=in high impedance mode

fields.name: psm_restart_flag
fields.doc:
This is set by psm_restart from the debugger.\n
                Its purpose is to branch bootcode to a safe mode when the debugger has issued a psm_restart in order to recover from a boot lock-up.\n
                In the safe mode the debugger can repair the boot code, clear this flag then reboot the processor.

fields.name: had_psm_restart
fields.doc: Last reset was from the debug port

fields.name: had_run
fields.doc: Last reset was from the RUN pin

fields.name: had_por
fields.doc: Last reset was from the power-on reset or brown-out detection blocks

tbman.name: tbman
tbman.doc: Testbench manager. Allows the programmer to know what platform their software is running on.

fields.name: fpga
fields.doc: Indicates the platform is an FPGA

fields.name: asic
fields.doc: Indicates the platform is an ASIC

tbman.platform.name: platform
tbman.platform.doc: Indicates the type of platform in use

dma.name: dma
dma.doc: DMA with separate read and write masters

dma.ch0_read_addr.name: ch0_read_addr
dma.ch0_read_addr.doc:
DMA Channel 0 Read Address pointer\n
            This register updates automatically each time a read completes. The current value is the next address to be read by this channel.

dma.ch0_write_addr.name: ch0_write_addr
dma.ch0_write_addr.doc:
DMA Channel 0 Write Address pointer\n
            This register updates automatically each time a write completes. The current value is the next address to be written by this channel.

dma.ch0_trans_count.name: ch0_trans_count
dma.ch0_trans_count.doc:
DMA Channel 0 Transfer Count

            Program the number of bus transfers a channel will perform before halting. Note that, if transfers are larger than one byte in size, this is not equal to the number of bytes transferred (see CTRL_DATA_SIZE).


            When the channel is active, reading this register shows the number of transfers remaining, updating automatically each time a write transfer completes.


            Writing this register sets the RELOAD value for the transfer counter. Each time this channel is triggered, the RELOAD value is copied into the live transfer counter. The channel can be started multiple times, and will perform the same number of transfers each time, as programmed by most recent write.


            The RELOAD value can be observed at CHx_DBG_TCR. If TRANS_COUNT is used as a trigger, the written value is used immediately as the length of the new transfer sequence, as well as being written to RELOAD.

fields.name: ahb_error
fields.doc: Logical OR of the READ_ERROR and WRITE_ERROR flags. The channel halts when it encounters any bus error, and always raises its channel IRQ flag.

fields.name: read_error
fields.doc:
If 1, the channel received a read bus error. Write one to clear.\n
                READ_ADDR shows the approximate address where the bus error was encountered (will not to be earlier, or more than 3 transfers later)

fields.name: write_error
fields.doc:
If 1, the channel received a write bus error. Write one to clear.\n
                WRITE_ADDR shows the approximate address where the bus error was encountered (will not to be earlier, or more than 5 transfers later)

fields.name: busy
fields.doc:
This flag goes high when the channel starts a new transfer sequence, and low when the last transfer of that sequence completes. Clearing EN while BUSY is high pauses the channel, and BUSY will stay high while paused.\n\n
                To terminate a sequence early (and clear the BUSY flag), see CHAN_ABORT.

fields.name: sniff_en
fields.doc:
If 1, this channel's data transfers are visible to the sniff hardware, and each transfer will advance the state of the checksum. This only applies if the sniff hardware is enabled, and has this channel selected.\n\n
                This allows checksum to be enabled or disabled on a per-control- block basis.

fields.name: bswap
fields.doc:
Apply byte-swap transformation to DMA data.\n
                For byte data, this has no effect. For halfword data, the two bytes of each halfword are swapped. For word data, the four bytes of each word are swapped to reverse order.

fields.name: irq_quiet
fields.doc:
In QUIET mode, the channel does not generate IRQs at the end of every transfer block. Instead, an IRQ is raised when NULL is written to a trigger register, indicating the end of a control block chain.\n\n
                This reduces the number of interrupts to be serviced by the CPU when transferring a DMA chain of many small control blocks.

fields.name: treq_sel
fields.doc:
Select a Transfer Request signal.\n
                The channel uses the transfer request signal to pace its data transfer rate. Sources for TREQ signals are internal (TIMERS) or external (DREQ, a Data Request from the system).\n
                0x0 to 0x3a -> select DREQ n as TREQ

fields.name: chain_to
fields.doc:
When this channel completes, it will trigger the channel indicated by CHAIN_TO. Disable by setting CHAIN_TO = _(this channel)_.\n
                Reset value is equal to channel number (0).

fields.name: ring_sel
fields.doc:
Select whether RING_SIZE applies to read or write addresses.\n
                If 0, read addresses are wrapped on a (1 << RING_SIZE) boundary. If 1, write addresses are wrapped.

fields.name: ring_size
fields.doc:
Size of address wrap region. If 0, don't wrap. For values n > 0, only the lower n bits of the address will change. This wraps the address on a (1 << n) byte boundary, facilitating access to naturally-aligned ring buffers.\n\n
                Ring sizes between 2 and 32768 bytes are possible. This can apply to either read or write addresses, based on value of RING_SEL.

fields.name: incr_write
fields.doc:
If 1, the write address increments with each transfer. If 0, each write is directed to the same, initial address.\n\n
                Generally this should be disabled for memory-to-peripheral transfers.

fields.name: incr_read
fields.doc:
If 1, the read address increments with each transfer. If 0, each read is directed to the same, initial address.\n\n
                Generally this should be disabled for peripheral-to-memory transfers.

fields.name: data_size
fields.doc: Set the size of each bus transfer (byte/halfword/word). READ_ADDR and WRITE_ADDR advance by this amount (1/2/4 bytes) with each transfer.

fields.name: high_priority
fields.doc:
HIGH_PRIORITY gives a channel preferential treatment in issue scheduling: in each scheduling round, all high priority channels are considered first, and then only a single low priority channel, before returning to the high priority channels.\n\n
                This only affects the order in which the DMA schedules channels. The DMA's bus priority is not changed. If the DMA is not saturated then a low priority channel will see no loss of throughput.

fields.name: en
fields.doc:
DMA Channel Enable.\n
                When 1, the channel will respond to triggering events, which will cause it to become BUSY and start transferring data. When 0, the channel will ignore triggers, stop issuing transfers, and pause the current transfer sequence (i.e. BUSY will remain high if already high)

dma.ch0_al1_trans_count_trig.name: ch0_al1_trans_count_trig
dma.ch0_al1_trans_count_trig.doc:
Alias for channel 0 TRANS_COUNT register\n
            This is a trigger register (0xc). Writing a nonzero value will\n
            reload the channel counter and start the channel.

dma.ch0_al2_write_addr_trig.name: ch0_al2_write_addr_trig
dma.ch0_al2_write_addr_trig.doc:
Alias for channel 0 WRITE_ADDR register\n
            This is a trigger register (0xc). Writing a nonzero value will\n
            reload the channel counter and start the channel.

dma.ch0_al3_read_addr_trig.name: ch0_al3_read_addr_trig
dma.ch0_al3_read_addr_trig.doc:
Alias for channel 0 READ_ADDR register\n
            This is a trigger register (0xc). Writing a nonzero value will\n
            reload the channel counter and start the channel.

dma.ch1_read_addr.name: ch1_read_addr
dma.ch1_read_addr.doc:
DMA Channel 1 Read Address pointer\n
            This register updates automatically each time a read completes. The current value is the next address to be read by this channel.

                0x0 to 0x3a -> select DREQ n as TREQ

fields.name: chain_to
fields.doc:
When this channel completes, it will trigger the channel indicated by CHAIN_TO. Disable by setting CHAIN_TO = _(this channel)_.\n
                Reset value is equal to channel number (3).

fields.name: ring_sel
fields.doc:
Select whether RING_SIZE applies to read or write addresses.\n
                If 0, read addresses are wrapped on a (1 << RING_SIZE) boundary. If 1, write addresses are wrapped.

fields.name: ring_size
fields.doc:
Size of address wrap region. If 0, don't wrap. For values n > 0, only the lower n bits of the address will change. This wraps the address on a (1 << n) byte boundary, facilitating access to naturally-aligned ring buffers.\n\n
                Ring sizes between 2 and 32768 bytes are possible. This can apply to either read or write addresses, based on value of RING_SEL.

fields.name: incr_write
fields.doc:
If 1, the write address increments with each transfer. If 0, each write is directed to the same, initial address.\n\n
                Generally this should be disabled for memory-to-peripheral transfers.

fields.name: incr_read
fields.doc:
If 1, the read address increments with each transfer. If 0, each read is directed to the same, initial address.\n\n
                Generally this should be disabled for peripheral-to-memory transfers.

fields.name: data_size
fields.doc: Set the size of each bus transfer (byte/halfword/word). READ_ADDR and WRITE_ADDR advance by this amount (1/2/4 bytes) with each transfer.

fields.name: high_priority
fields.doc:
HIGH_PRIORITY gives a channel preferential treatment in issue scheduling: in each scheduling round, all high priority channels are considered first, and then only a single low priority channel, before returning to the high priority channels.\n\n
                This only affects the order in which the DMA schedules channels. The DMA's bus priority is not changed. If the DMA is not saturated then a low priority channel will see no loss of throughput.

fields.name: en
fields.doc:
DMA Channel Enable.\n
                When 1, the channel will respond to triggering events, which will cause it to become BUSY and start transferring data. When 0, the channel will ignore triggers, stop issuing transfers, and pause the current transfer sequence (i.e. BUSY will remain high if already high)

dma.ch3_al1_trans_count_trig.name: ch3_al1_trans_count_trig
dma.ch3_al1_trans_count_trig.doc:
Alias for channel 3 TRANS_COUNT register\n
            This is a trigger register (0xc). Writing a nonzero value will\n
            reload the channel counter and start the channel.

dma.ch3_al2_write_addr_trig.name: ch3_al2_write_addr_trig
dma.ch3_al2_write_addr_trig.doc:
Alias for channel 3 WRITE_ADDR register\n
            This is a trigger register (0xc). Writing a nonzero value will\n
            reload the channel counter and start the channel.

dma.ch3_al3_read_addr_trig.name: ch3_al3_read_addr_trig
dma.ch3_al3_read_addr_trig.doc:
Alias for channel 3 READ_ADDR register\n
            This is a trigger register (0xc). Writing a nonzero value will\n
            reload the channel counter and start the channel.

dma.ch4_read_addr.name: ch4_read_addr
dma.ch4_read_addr.doc:
DMA Channel 4 Read Address pointer\n
            This register updates automatically each time a read completes. The current value is the next address to be read by this channel.

dma.ch4_write_addr.name: ch4_write_addr
dma.ch4_write_addr.doc:
DMA Channel 4 Write Address pointer\n
            This register updates automatically each time a write completes. The current value is the next address to be written by this channel.

dma.ch4_trans_count.name: ch4_trans_count
dma.ch4_trans_count.doc:
DMA Channel 4 Transfer Count

            Program the number of bus transfers a channel will perform before halting. Note that, if transfers are larger than one byte in size, this is not equal to the number of bytes transferred (see CTRL_DATA_SIZE).


            When the channel is active, reading this register shows the number of transfers remaining, updating automatically each time a write transfer completes.


            Writing this register sets the RELOAD value for the transfer counter. Each time this channel is triggered, the RELOAD value is copied into the live transfer counter. The channel can be started multiple times, and will perform the same number of transfers each time, as programmed by most recent write.


            The RELOAD value can be observed at CHx_DBG_TCR. If TRANS_COUNT is used as a trigger, the written value is used immediately as the length of the new transfer sequence, as well as being written to RELOAD.

fields.name: ahb_error
fields.doc: Logical OR of the READ_ERROR and WRITE_ERROR flags. The channel halts when it encounters any bus error, and always raises its channel IRQ flag.

fields.name: read_error
fields.doc:
If 1, the channel received a read bus error. Write one to clear.\n
                READ_ADDR shows the approximate address where the bus error was encountered (will not to be earlier, or more than 3 transfers later)

fields.name: write_error
fields.doc:
If 1, the channel received a write bus error. Write one to clear.\n
                WRITE_ADDR shows the approximate address where the bus error was encountered (will not to be earlier, or more than 5 transfers later)

fields.name: busy
fields.doc:
This flag goes high when the channel starts a new transfer sequence, and low when the last transfer of that sequence completes. Clearing EN while BUSY is high pauses the channel, and BUSY will stay high while paused.\n\n
                To terminate a sequence early (and clear the BUSY flag), see CHAN_ABORT.

fields.name: sniff_en
fields.doc:
If 1, this channel's data transfers are visible to the sniff hardware, and each transfer will advance the state of the checksum. This only applies if the sniff hardware is enabled, and has this channel selected.\n\n
                This allows checksum to be enabled or disabled on a per-control- block basis.

fields.name: bswap
fields.doc:
Apply byte-swap transformation to DMA data.\n
                For byte data, this has no effect. For halfword data, the two bytes of each halfword are swapped. For word data, the four bytes of each word are swapped to reverse order.

fields.name: irq_quiet
fields.doc:
In QUIET mode, the channel does not generate IRQs at the end of every transfer block. Instead, an IRQ is raised when NULL is written to a trigger register, indicating the end of a control block chain.\n\n
                This reduces the number of interrupts to be serviced by the CPU when transferring a DMA chain of many small control blocks.

fields.name: treq_sel

                0x0 to 0x3a -> select DREQ n as TREQ

Alias for channel 7 WRITE_ADDR register\n
            This is a trigger register (0xc). Writing a nonzero value will\n
            reload the channel counter and start the channel.

dma.ch7_al3_read_addr_trig.name: ch7_al3_read_addr_trig
dma.ch7_al3_read_addr_trig.doc:
Alias for channel 7 READ_ADDR register\n
            This is a trigger register (0xc). Writing a nonzero value will\n
            reload the channel counter and start the channel.

dma.ch8_read_addr.name: ch8_read_addr
dma.ch8_read_addr.doc:
DMA Channel 8 Read Address pointer\n
            This register updates automatically each time a read completes. The current value is the next address to be read by this channel.

dma.ch8_write_addr.name: ch8_write_addr
dma.ch8_write_addr.doc:
DMA Channel 8 Write Address pointer\n
            This register updates automatically each time a write completes. The current value is the next address to be written by this channel.

dma.ch8_trans_count.name: ch8_trans_count
dma.ch8_trans_count.doc:
DMA Channel 8 Transfer Count

            Program the number of bus transfers a channel will perform before halting. Note that, if transfers are larger than one byte in size, this is not equal to the number of bytes transferred (see CTRL_DATA_SIZE).


            When the channel is active, reading this register shows the number of transfers remaining, updating automatically each time a write transfer completes.


            Writing this register sets the RELOAD value for the transfer counter. Each time this channel is triggered, the RELOAD value is copied into the live transfer counter. The channel can be started multiple times, and will perform the same number of transfers each time, as programmed by most recent write.


            The RELOAD value can be observed at CHx_DBG_TCR. If TRANS_COUNT is used as a trigger, the written value is used immediately as the length of the new transfer sequence, as well as being written to RELOAD.

fields.name: ahb_error
fields.doc: Logical OR of the READ_ERROR and WRITE_ERROR flags. The channel halts when it encounters any bus error, and always raises its channel IRQ flag.

fields.name: read_error
fields.doc:
If 1, the channel received a read bus error. Write one to clear.\n
                READ_ADDR shows the approximate address where the bus error was encountered (will not to be earlier, or more than 3 transfers later)

fields.name: write_error
fields.doc:
If 1, the channel received a write bus error. Write one to clear.\n
                WRITE_ADDR shows the approximate address where the bus error was encountered (will not to be earlier, or more than 5 transfers later)

fields.name: busy
fields.doc:
This flag goes high when the channel starts a new transfer sequence, and low when the last transfer of that sequence completes. Clearing EN while BUSY is high pauses the channel, and BUSY will stay high while paused.\n\n
                To terminate a sequence early (and clear the BUSY flag), see CHAN_ABORT.

fields.name: sniff_en
fields.doc:
If 1, this channel's data transfers are visible to the sniff hardware, and each transfer will advance the state of the checksum. This only applies if the sniff hardware is enabled, and has this channel selected.\n\n
                This allows checksum to be enabled or disabled on a per-control- block basis.

fields.name: bswap
fields.doc:
Apply byte-swap transformation to DMA data.\n
                For byte data, this has no effect. For halfword data, the two bytes of each halfword are swapped. For word data, the four bytes of each word are swapped to reverse order.

fields.name: irq_quiet
fields.doc:
In QUIET mode, the channel does not generate IRQs at the end of every transfer block. Instead, an IRQ is raised when NULL is written to a trigger register, indicating the end of a control block chain.\n\n
                This reduces the number of interrupts to be serviced by the CPU when transferring a DMA chain of many small control blocks.

fields.name: treq_sel
fields.doc:
Select a Transfer Request signal.\n
                The channel uses the transfer request signal to pace its data transfer rate. Sources for TREQ signals are internal (TIMERS) or external (DREQ, a Data Request from the system).\n
                0x0 to 0x3a -> select DREQ n as TREQ

fields.name: chain_to
fields.doc:
When this channel completes, it will trigger the channel indicated by CHAIN_TO. Disable by setting CHAIN_TO = _(this channel)_.\n
                Reset value is equal to channel number (8).

fields.name: ring_sel
fields.doc:
Select whether RING_SIZE applies to read or write addresses.\n
                If 0, read addresses are wrapped on a (1 << RING_SIZE) boundary. If 1, write addresses are wrapped.

fields.name: ring_size
fields.doc:
Size of address wrap region. If 0, don't wrap. For values n > 0, only the lower n bits of the address will change. This wraps the address on a (1 << n) byte boundary, facilitating access to naturally-aligned ring buffers.\n\n
                Ring sizes between 2 and 32768 bytes are possible. This can apply to either read or write addresses, based on value of RING_SEL.

fields.name: incr_write
fields.doc:
If 1, the write address increments with each transfer. If 0, each write is directed to the same, initial address.\n\n
                Generally this should be disabled for memory-to-peripheral transfers.

fields.name: incr_read
fields.doc:
If 1, the read address increments with each transfer. If 0, each read is directed to the same, initial address.\n\n
                Generally this should be disabled for peripheral-to-memory transfers.

fields.name: data_size
fields.doc: Set the size of each bus transfer (byte/halfword/word). READ_ADDR and WRITE_ADDR advance by this amount (1/2/4 bytes) with each transfer.

fields.name: high_priority
fields.doc:
HIGH_PRIORITY gives a channel preferential treatment in issue scheduling: in each scheduling round, all high priority channels are considered first, and then only a single low priority channel, before returning to the high priority channels.\n\n
                This only affects the order in which the DMA schedules channels. The DMA's bus priority is not changed. If the DMA is not saturated then a low priority channel will see no loss of throughput.

fields.name: en
fields.doc:
DMA Channel Enable.\n
                When 1, the channel will respond to triggering events, which will cause it to become BUSY and start transferring data. When 0, the channel will ignore triggers, stop issuing transfers, and pause the current transfer sequence (i.e. BUSY will remain high if already high)

dma.ch8_al1_trans_count_trig.name: ch8_al1_trans_count_trig
dma.ch8_al1_trans_count_trig.doc:
Alias for channel 8 TRANS_COUNT register\n
            This is a trigger register (0xc). Writing a nonzero value will\n
            reload the channel counter and start the channel.

dma.ch8_al3_read_addr_trig.name: ch8_al3_read_addr_trig

fields.name: intr
fields.doc:
Raw interrupt status for DMA Channels 0..15. Bit n corresponds to channel n. Ignores any masking or forcing. Channel interrupts can be cleared by writing a bit mask to INTR, INTS0 or INTS1.


                Channel interrupts can be routed to either of two system-level IRQs based on INTE0 and INTE1.


                This can be used vector different channel interrupts to different ISRs: this might be done to allow NVIC IRQ preemption for more time-critical channels, or to spread IRQ load across different cores.


                It is also valid to ignore this behaviour and just use INTE0/INTS0/IRQ 0.

fields.name: inte0
fields.doc: Set bit n to pass interrupts from channel n to DMA IRQ 0.

fields.name: intf0
fields.doc: Write 1s to force the corresponding bits in INTE0. The interrupt remains asserted until INTF0 is cleared.

fields.name: ints0
fields.doc:
Indicates active channel interrupt requests which are currently causing IRQ 0 to be asserted.\n
                Channel interrupts can be cleared by writing a bit mask here.

fields.name: inte1
fields.doc: Set bit n to pass interrupts from channel n to DMA IRQ 1.

fields.name: intf1
fields.doc: Write 1s to force the corresponding bits in INTE0. The interrupt remains asserted until INTF0 is cleared.

fields.name: ints1
fields.doc:
Indicates active channel interrupt requests which are currently causing IRQ 1 to be asserted.\n
                Channel interrupts can be cleared by writing a bit mask here.

fields.name: x
fields.doc: Pacing Timer Dividend. Specifies the X value for the (X/Y) fractional timer.

fields.name: y
fields.doc: Pacing Timer Divisor. Specifies the Y value for the (X/Y) fractional timer.

dma.timer0.name: timer0
dma.timer0.doc:
Pacing (X/Y) Fractional Timer\n
            The pacing timer produces TREQ assertions at a rate set by ((X/Y) * sys_clk). This equation is evaluated every sys_clk cycles and therefore can only generate TREQs at a rate of 1 per sys_clk (i.e. permanent TREQ) or less.

fields.name: x
fields.doc: Pacing Timer Dividend. Specifies the X value for the (X/Y) fractional timer.

fields.name: y
fields.doc: Pacing Timer Divisor. Specifies the Y value for the (X/Y) fractional timer.

dma.timer1.name: timer1
dma.timer1.doc:
Pacing (X/Y) Fractional Timer\n
            The pacing timer produces TREQ assertions at a rate set by ((X/Y) * sys_clk). This equation is evaluated every sys_clk cycles and therefore can only generate TREQs at a rate of 1 per sys_clk (i.e. permanent TREQ) or less.

fields.name: multi_chan_trigger
fields.doc: Each bit in this register corresponds to a DMA channel. Writing a 1 to the relevant bit is the same as writing to that channel's trigger register; the channel will start if it is currently enabled and not already busy.

dma.multi_chan_trigger.name: multi_chan_trigger
dma.multi_chan_trigger.doc: Trigger one or more channels simultaneously

fields.name: out_inv
fields.doc: If set, the result appears inverted (bitwise complement) when read. This does not affect the way the checksum is calculated; the result is transformed on-the-fly between the result register and the bus.

fields.name: out_rev
fields.doc: If set, the result appears bit-reversed when read. This does not affect the way the checksum is calculated; the result is transformed on-the-fly between the result register and the bus.

fields.name: bswap
fields.doc:
Locally perform a byte reverse on the sniffed data, before feeding into checksum.\n\n
                Note that the sniff hardware is downstream of the DMA channel byteswap performed in the read master: if channel CTRL_BSWAP and SNIFF_CTRL_BSWAP are both enabled, their effects cancel from the sniffer's point of view.

fields.name: dmach
fields.doc: DMA channel for Sniffer to observe

dma.sniff_data.name: sniff_data
dma.sniff_data.doc:
Data accumulator for sniff hardware\n
            Write an initial seed value here before starting a DMA transfer on the channel indicated by SNIFF_CTRL_DMACH. The hardware will update this register each time it observes a read from the indicated channel. Once the channel completes, the final result can be read from this register.

fields.name: chan_abort
fields.doc:
Each bit corresponds to a channel. Writing a 1 aborts whatever transfer sequence is in progress on that channel. The bit will remain high until any in-flight transfers have been flushed through the address and data FIFOs.\n\n
                After writing, this register must be polled until it returns all-zero. Until this point, it is unsafe to restart the channel.

dma.chan_abort.name: chan_abort
dma.chan_abort.doc: Abort an in-progress transfer sequence on one or more channels

dma.n_channels.name: n_channels
dma.n_channels.doc: The number of channels this DMA instance is equipped with. This DMA supports up to 16 hardware channels, but can be configured with as few as one, to minimise silicon area.

dma.ch0_dbg_ctdreq.name: ch0_dbg_ctdreq
dma.ch0_dbg_ctdreq.doc: Read: get channel DREQ counter (i.e. how many accesses the DMA expects it can perform on the peripheral without overflow/underflow. Write any value: clears the counter, and cause channel to re-initiate DREQ handshake.

dma.ch0_dbg_tcr.name: ch0_dbg_tcr
dma.ch0_dbg_tcr.doc: Read to get channel TRANS_COUNT reload value, i.e. the length of the next transfer

dma.ch1_dbg_ctdreq.name: ch1_dbg_ctdreq
dma.ch1_dbg_ctdreq.doc: Read: get channel DREQ counter (i.e. how many accesses the DMA expects it can perform on the peripheral without overflow/underflow. Write any value: clears the counter, and cause channel to re-initiate DREQ handshake.

fields.name: endpoint
fields.doc: Device endpoint to send data to. Only valid for HOST mode.

fields.name: address
fields.doc: In device mode, the address that the device should respond to. Set in response to a SET_ADDR setup packet from the host. In host mode set to the address of the device to communicate with.

fields.name: intep_preamble
fields.doc: Interrupt EP requires preamble (is a low speed device on a full speed hub)

fields.name: intep_dir
fields.doc: Direction of the interrupt endpoint. In=0, Out=1

fields.name: endpoint
fields.doc: Endpoint number of the interrupt endpoint

usbctrl_regs.addr_endp1.name: addr_endp1
usbctrl_regs.addr_endp1.doc: Interrupt endpoint 1. Only valid for HOST mode.

usbctrl_regs.addr_endp15.name: addr_endp15
usbctrl_regs.addr_endp15.doc: Interrupt endpoint 15. Only valid for HOST mode.

usbctrl_regs.sof_wr.name: sof_wr
usbctrl_regs.sof_wr.doc: Set the SOF (Start of Frame) frame number in the host controller. The SOF packet is sent every 1ms and the host will increment the frame number by 1 each time.

usbctrl_regs.sof_rd.name: sof_rd
usbctrl_regs.sof_rd.doc: Read the last SOF (Start of Frame) frame number seen. In device mode the last SOF received from the host. In host mode the last SOF sent by the host.

fields.name: ep0_int_stall
fields.doc: Device: Set bit in EP_STATUS_STALL_NAK when EP0 sends a STALL

fields.name: ep0_double_buf
fields.doc: Device: EP0 single buffered = 0, double buffered = 1

fields.name: ep0_int_1buf
fields.doc: Device: Set bit in BUFF_STATUS for every buffer completed on EP0

fields.name: ep0_int_2buf
fields.doc: Device: Set bit in BUFF_STATUS for every 2 buffers completed on EP0

fields.name: ep0_int_nak
fields.doc: Device: Set bit in EP_STATUS_STALL_NAK when EP0 sends a NAK

fields.name: resume
fields.doc: Device: Remote wakeup. Device can initiate its own resume after suspend.

fields.name: keep_alive_en
fields.doc: Host: Enable keep alive packet (for low speed bus)

fields.name: sof_en
fields.doc: Host: Enable SOF generation (for full speed bus)

fields.name: sof_sync
fields.doc: Host: Delay packet(s) until after SOF

fields.name: preamble_en
fields.doc: Host: Preable enable for LS device on FS hub

fields.name: data_seq_error
fields.doc:
Data Sequence Error.


                The device can raise a sequence error in the following conditions:


                * A SETUP packet is received followed by a DATA1 packet (data phase should always be DATA0) * An OUT packet is received from the host but doesn't match the data pid in the buffer control register read from DPSRAM


                The host can raise a data sequence error in the following conditions:


                * An IN packet from the device has the wrong data PID

fields.name: ack_rec
fields.doc: ACK received. Raised by both host and device.

fields.name: rx_timeout
fields.doc: RX timeout is raised by both the host and device if an ACK is not received in the maximum time specified by the USB spec.

fields.name: rx_overflow
fields.doc: RX overflow is raised by the Serial RX engine if the incoming data is too fast.

fields.name: bit_stuff_error
fields.doc: Bit Stuff Error. Raised by the Serial RX engine.

fields.name: crc_error
fields.doc: CRC Error. Raised by the Serial RX engine.

fields.name: trans_complete
fields.doc:
Transaction complete.


                Raised by device if:


                * An IN or OUT packet is sent with the `LAST_BUFF` bit set in the buffer control register


                Raised by host if:


                * A setup packet is sent when no data in or data out transaction follows * An IN packet is received and the `LAST_BUFF` bit is set in the buffer control register * An IN packet is received with zero length * An OUT packet is sent and the `LAST_BUFF` bit is set

fields.name: resume
fields.doc: Host: Device has initiated a remote resume. Device: host has initiated a resume.

fields.name: speed
fields.doc: Host: device speed. Disconnected = 00, LS = 01, FS = 10

fields.name: suspended
fields.doc: Bus in suspended state. Valid for device and host. Host and device will go into suspend if neither Keep Alive / SOF frames are enabled.

usbctrl_regs.buff_status.name: buff_status
usbctrl_regs.buff_status.doc: Buffer status register. A bit set here indicates that a buffer has completed on the endpoint (if the buffer interrupt is enabled). It is possible for 2 buffers to be completed, so clearing the buffer status bit may instantly re set it on the next clock cycle.

usbctrl_regs.buff_cpu_should_handle.name: buff_cpu_should_handle
usbctrl_regs.buff_cpu_should_handle.doc: Which of the double buffers should be handled. Only valid if using an interrupt per buffer (i.e. not per 2 buffers). Not valid for host interrupt endpoint polling because they are only single buffered.

usbctrl_regs.ep_abort.name: ep_abort
usbctrl_regs.ep_abort.doc: Device only: Can be set to ignore the buffer control register for this endpoint in case you would like to revoke a buffer. A NAK will be sent for every access to the endpoint until this bit is cleared. A corresponding bit in `EP_ABORT_DONE` is set when it is safe to modify the buffer control register.

usbctrl_regs.ep_abort_done.name: ep_abort_done
usbctrl_regs.ep_abort_done.doc: Device only: Used in conjunction with `EP_ABORT`. Set once an endpoint is idle so the programmer knows it is safe to modify the buffer control register.

usbctrl_regs.ep_stall_arm.name: ep_stall_arm
usbctrl_regs.ep_stall_arm.doc: Device: this bit must be set in conjunction with the `STALL` bit in the buffer control register to send a STALL on EP0. The device controller clears these bits when a SETUP packet is received because the USB spec requires that a STALL condition is cleared when a SETUP packet is received.

fields.name: delay_fs
fields.doc: NAK polling interval for a full speed device

fields.name: delay_ls
fields.doc: NAK polling interval for a low speed device

usbctrl_regs.nak_poll.name: nak_poll
usbctrl_regs.nak_poll.doc: Used by the host controller. Sets the wait time in microseconds before trying again if the device replies with a NAK.

usbctrl_regs.ep_status_stall_nak.name: ep_status_stall_nak
usbctrl_regs.ep_status_stall_nak.doc: Device: bits are set when the `IRQ_ON_NAK` or `IRQ_ON_STALL` bits are set. For EP0 this comes from `SIE_CTRL`. For all other endpoints it comes from the endpoint control register.

usbctrl_regs.usb_muxing.name: usb_muxing
usbctrl_regs.usb_muxing.doc: Where to connect the USB controller. Should be to_phy by default.

usbctrl_regs.usb_pwr.name: usb_pwr
usbctrl_regs.usb_pwr.doc: Overrides for the power signals in the event that the VBUS signals are not hooked up to GPIO. Set the value of the override and then the override enable to switch over to the override value.

fields.name: tx_diffmode
fields.doc:
TX_DIFFMODE=0: Single ended mode\n
                TX_DIFFMODE=1: Differential drive mode (TX_DM, TX_DM_OE ignored)

fields.name: tx_fsslew
fields.doc:
TX_FSSLEW=0: Low speed slew rate\n
                TX_FSSLEW=1: Full speed slew rate

fields.name: tx_pd
fields.doc: TX power down override (if override enable is set). 1 = powered down.

fields.name: rx_pd
fields.doc: RX power down override (if override enable is set). 1 = powered down.

fields.name: tx_dm
fields.doc:
Output data. TX_DIFFMODE=1, Ignored\n
                TX_DIFFMODE=0, Drives DPM only. TX_DM_OE=1 to enable drive. DPM=TX_DM

fields.name: tx_dp
fields.doc:
Output data. If TX_DIFFMODE=1, Drives DPP/DPM diff pair. TX_DP_OE=1 to enable drive. DPP=TX_DP, DPM=~TX_DP\n
                If TX_DIFFMODE=0, Drives DPP only. TX_DP_OE=1 to enable drive. DPP=TX_DP

fields.name: tx_dm_oe
fields.doc:
Output enable. If TX_DIFFMODE=1, Ignored.\n
                If TX_DIFFMODE=0, OE for DPM only. 0 - DPM in Hi-Z state; 1 - DPM driving

fields.name: tx_dp_oe
fields.doc:
Output enable. If TX_DIFFMODE=1, OE for DPP/DPM diff pair. 0 - DPP/DPM in Hi-Z state; 1 - DPP/DPM driving\n
                If TX_DIFFMODE=0, OE for DPP only. 0 - DPP in Hi-Z state; 1 - DPP driving

fields.name: dm_pullup_hisel
fields.doc: Enable the second DM pull up resistor. 0 - Pull = Rpu2; 1 - Pull = Rpu1 + Rpu2

fields.name: dp_pullup_hisel
fields.doc: Enable the second DP pull up resistor. 0 - Pull = Rpu2; 1 - Pull = Rpu1 + Rpu2

usbctrl_regs.usbphy_direct.name: usbphy_direct
usbctrl_regs.usbphy_direct.doc: This register allows for direct control of the USB phy. Use in conjunction with usbphy_direct_override register to enable each override bit.

usbctrl_regs.usbphy_direct_override.name: usbphy_direct_override
usbctrl_regs.usbphy_direct_override.doc: Override enable for each control in usbphy_direct

fields.name: dm_pulldn_trim
fields.doc:
Value to drive to USB PHY\n
                DM pulldown resistor trim control\n
                Experimental data suggests that the reset value will work, but this register allows adjustment if required

fields.name: dp_pulldn_trim
fields.doc:
Value to drive to USB PHY\n
                DP pulldown resistor trim control\n
                Experimental data suggests that the reset value will work, but this register allows adjustment if required

usbctrl_regs.usbphy_trim.name: usbphy_trim
usbctrl_regs.usbphy_trim.doc: Used to adjust trim values of USB phy pull down resistors.

fields.name: ep_stall_nak
fields.doc: Raised when any bit in EP_STATUS_STALL_NAK is set. Clear by clearing all bits in EP_STATUS_STALL_NAK.

fields.name: abort_done
fields.doc: Raised when any bit in ABORT_DONE is set. Clear by clearing all bits in ABORT_DONE.

fields.name: dev_sof
fields.doc: Set every time the device receives a SOF (Start of Frame) packet. Cleared by reading SOF_RD

fields.name: dev_resume_from_host
fields.doc: Set when the device receives a resume from the host. Cleared by writing to SIE_STATUS.RESUME

fields.name: dev_suspend
fields.doc: Set when the device suspend state changes. Cleared by writing to SIE_STATUS.SUSPENDED

fields.name: dev_conn_dis
fields.doc: Set when the device connection state changes. Cleared by writing to SIE_STATUS.CONNECTED

fields.name: buff_status
fields.doc: Raised when any bit in BUFF_STATUS is set. Clear by clearing all bits in BUFF_STATUS.

fields.name: trans_complete
fields.doc: Raised every time SIE_STATUS.TRANS_COMPLETE is set. Clear by writing to this bit.

fields.name: host_sof
fields.doc: Host: raised every time the host sends a SOF (Start of Frame). Cleared by reading SOF_RD

fields.name: host_resume
fields.doc: Host: raised when a device wakes up the host. Cleared by writing to SIE_STATUS.RESUME

fields.name: host_conn_dis
fields.doc: Host: raised when a device is connected or disconnected (i.e. when SIE_STATUS.SPEED changes). Cleared by writing to SIE_STATUS.SPEED

fields.name: ep_stall_nak
fields.doc: Raised when any bit in EP_STATUS_STALL_NAK is set. Clear by clearing all bits in EP_STATUS_STALL_NAK.

fields.name: abort_done
fields.doc: Raised when any bit in ABORT_DONE is set. Clear by clearing all bits in ABORT_DONE.

fields.name: dev_sof
fields.doc: Set every time the device receives a SOF (Start of Frame) packet. Cleared by reading SOF_RD

fields.name: dev_resume_from_host
fields.doc: Set when the device receives a resume from the host. Cleared by writing to SIE_STATUS.RESUME

fields.name: dev_suspend
fields.doc: Set when the device suspend state changes. Cleared by writing to SIE_STATUS.SUSPENDED

fields.name: dev_conn_dis
fields.doc: Set when the device connection state changes. Cleared by writing to SIE_STATUS.CONNECTED

fields.name: buff_status
fields.doc: Raised when any bit in BUFF_STATUS is set. Clear by clearing all bits in BUFF_STATUS.

fields.name: trans_complete
fields.doc: Raised every time SIE_STATUS.TRANS_COMPLETE is set. Clear by writing to this bit.

fields.name: host_sof
fields.doc: Host: raised every time the host sends a SOF (Start of Frame). Cleared by reading SOF_RD

fields.name: host_resume
fields.doc: Host: raised when a device wakes up the host. Cleared by writing to SIE_STATUS.RESUME

fields.name: host_conn_dis
fields.doc: Host: raised when a device is connected or disconnected (i.e. when SIE_STATUS.SPEED changes). Cleared by writing to SIE_STATUS.SPEED

fields.name: ep_stall_nak
fields.doc: Raised when any bit in EP_STATUS_STALL_NAK is set. Clear by clearing all bits in EP_STATUS_STALL_NAK.

fields.name: abort_done
fields.doc: Raised when any bit in ABORT_DONE is set. Clear by clearing all bits in ABORT_DONE.

fields.name: dev_sof
fields.doc: Set every time the device receives a SOF (Start of Frame) packet. Cleared by reading SOF_RD

fields.name: dev_resume_from_host
fields.doc: Set when the device receives a resume from the host. Cleared by writing to SIE_STATUS.RESUME

fields.name: dev_suspend
fields.doc: Set when the device suspend state changes. Cleared by writing to SIE_STATUS.SUSPENDED

fields.name: dev_conn_dis
fields.doc: Set when the device connection state changes. Cleared by writing to SIE_STATUS.CONNECTED

fields.name: buff_status
fields.doc: Raised when any bit in BUFF_STATUS is set. Clear by clearing all bits in BUFF_STATUS.

fields.name: trans_complete
fields.doc: Raised every time SIE_STATUS.TRANS_COMPLETE is set. Clear by writing to this bit.

fields.name: host_sof
fields.doc: Host: raised every time the host sends a SOF (Start of Frame). Cleared by reading SOF_RD

fields.name: host_resume
fields.doc: Host: raised when a device wakes up the host. Cleared by writing to SIE_STATUS.RESUME

fields.name: host_conn_dis
fields.doc: Host: raised when a device is connected or disconnected (i.e. when SIE_STATUS.SPEED changes). Cleared by writing to SIE_STATUS.SPEED

fields.name: ep_stall_nak
fields.doc: Raised when any bit in EP_STATUS_STALL_NAK is set. Clear by clearing all bits in EP_STATUS_STALL_NAK.

fields.name: abort_done
fields.doc: Raised when any bit in ABORT_DONE is set. Clear by clearing all bits in ABORT_DONE.

fields.name: dev_resume_from_host
fields.doc: Set when the device receives a resume from the host. Cleared by writing to SIE_STATUS.RESUME

fields.name: dev_suspend
fields.doc: Set when the device suspend state changes. Cleared by writing to SIE_STATUS.SUSPENDED

fields.name: dev_conn_dis
fields.doc: Set when the device connection state changes. Cleared by writing to SIE_STATUS.CONNECTED

fields.name: buff_status
fields.doc: Raised when any bit in BUFF_STATUS is set. Clear by clearing all bits in BUFF_STATUS.

fields.name: trans_complete
fields.doc: Raised every time SIE_STATUS.TRANS_COMPLETE is set. Clear by writing to this bit.

fields.name: host_conn_dis
