fields.name: clkdiv_restart
fields.doc:
Force clock dividers to restart their count and clear fractional\n
                accumulators. Restart multiple dividers to synchronise them.

fields.name: sm_restart
fields.doc:
Clear internal SM state which is otherwise difficult to access\n
                (e.g. shift counters). Self-clearing.

fields.name: txempty
fields.doc: State machine TX FIFO is empty

fields.name: txfull
fields.doc: State machine TX FIFO is full

fields.name: rxempty
fields.doc: State machine RX FIFO is empty

fields.name: rxfull
fields.doc: State machine RX FIFO is full

fields.name: txstall
fields.doc: State machine has stalled on empty TX FIFO. Write 1 to clear.

fields.name: txover
fields.doc: TX FIFO overflow has occurred. Write 1 to clear.

fields.name: rxunder
fields.doc: RX FIFO underflow has occurred. Write 1 to clear.

fields.name: rxstall
fields.doc: State machine has stalled on full RX FIFO. Write 1 to clear.

pio0.txf0.name: txf0
pio0.txf0.doc: Direct write access to the TX FIFO for this state machine. Each write pushes one word to the FIFO.

pio0.txf1.name: txf1
pio0.txf1.doc: Direct write access to the TX FIFO for this state machine. Each write pushes one word to the FIFO.

pio0.txf2.name: txf2
pio0.txf2.doc: Direct write access to the TX FIFO for this state machine. Each write pushes one word to the FIFO.

pio0.txf3.name: txf3
pio0.txf3.doc: Direct write access to the TX FIFO for this state machine. Each write pushes one word to the FIFO.

pio0.rxf0.name: rxf0
pio0.rxf0.doc: Direct read access to the RX FIFO for this state machine. Each read pops one word from the FIFO.

pio0.rxf1.name: rxf1
pio0.rxf1.doc: Direct read access to the RX FIFO for this state machine. Each read pops one word from the FIFO.

pio0.rxf2.name: rxf2
pio0.rxf2.doc: Direct read access to the RX FIFO for this state machine. Each read pops one word from the FIFO.

pio0.rxf3.name: rxf3
pio0.rxf3.doc: Direct read access to the RX FIFO for this state machine. Each read pops one word from the FIFO.

pio0.irq.name: irq
pio0.irq.doc: Interrupt request register. Write 1 to clear

pio0.irq_force.name: irq_force
pio0.irq_force.doc:
Writing a 1 to each of these bits will forcibly assert the corresponding IRQ.\n
            Note this is different to the INTF register: writing here affects PIO internal\n
            state. INTF just asserts the processor-facing IRQ signal for testing ISRs,\n
            and is not visible to the state machines.

pio0.input_sync_bypass.name: input_sync_bypass
pio0.input_sync_bypass.doc:
There is a 2-flipflop synchronizer on each GPIO input, which protects\n
            PIO logic from metastabilities. This increases input delay, and for fast\n
            synchronous IO (e.g. SPI) these synchronizers may need to be bypassed.\n
            Each bit in this register corresponds to one GPIO.\n
            0 -> input is synchronized (default)\n
            1 -> synchronizer is bypassed\n
            If in doubt, leave this register as all zeroes.

pio0.dbg_padout.name: dbg_padout
pio0.dbg_padout.doc: Read to sample the pad output values PIO is currently driving to the GPIOs.

pio0.dbg_padoe.name: dbg_padoe
pio0.dbg_padoe.doc: Read to sample the pad output enables (direction) PIO is currently driving to the GPIOs.

fields.name: imem_size
fields.doc: The size of the instruction memory, measured in units of one instruction

fields.name: sm_count
fields.doc: The number of state machines this PIO instance is equipped with.

fields.name: fifo_depth
fields.doc:
The depth of the state machine TX/RX FIFOs, measured in words.\n
                Joining fifos via SHIFTCTRL_FJOIN gives one FIFO with double\n
                this depth.

pio0.dbg_cfginfo.name: dbg_cfginfo
pio0.dbg_cfginfo.doc:
The PIO hardware has some free parameters that may vary between chip products.\n
            These should be provided in the chip datasheet, but are also exposed here.

fields.name: int
fields.doc:
Effective frequency is sysclk/int.\n
                Value of 0 is interpreted as max possible value

pio0.sm0_clkdiv.name: sm0_clkdiv
pio0.sm0_clkdiv.doc:
Clock divider register for state machine 0\n
            Frequency = clock freq / (CLKDIV_INT + CLKDIV_FRAC / 256)

fields.name: exec_stalled
fields.doc:
An instruction written to SMx_INSTR is stalled, and latched by the\n
                state machine. Will clear once the instruction completes.

fields.name: side_en
fields.doc:
If 1, the delay MSB is used as side-set enable, rather than a\n
                side-set data bit. This allows instructions to perform side-set optionally,\n
                rather than on every instruction.

fields.name: side_pindir
fields.doc: Side-set data is asserted to pin OEs instead of pin values

fields.name: jmp_pin
fields.doc: The GPIO number to use as condition for JMP PIN. Unaffected by input mapping.

fields.name: out_en_sel
fields.doc: Which data bit to use for inline OUT enable

fields.name: inline_out_en
fields.doc:
If 1, use a bit of OUT data as an auxiliary write enable\n
                When used in conjunction with OUT_STICKY, writes with an enable of 0 will\n
                deassert the latest pin write. This can create useful masking/override behaviour\n
                due to the priority ordering of state machine pin writes (SM0 < SM1 < ...)

fields.name: out_sticky
fields.doc: Continuously assert the most recent OUT/SET to the pins

fields.name: wrap_top
fields.doc:
After reaching this address, execution is wrapped to wrap_bottom.\n
                If the instruction is a jump, and the jump condition is true, the jump takes priority.

fields.name: wrap_bottom
fields.doc: After reaching wrap_top, execution is wrapped to this address.

fields.name: status_sel
fields.doc: Comparison used for the MOV x, STATUS instruction.

fields.name: status_n
fields.doc: Comparison level for the MOV x, STATUS instruction

fields.name: fjoin_rx
fields.doc:
When 1, RX FIFO steals the TX FIFO's storage, and becomes twice as deep.\n
                TX FIFO is disabled as a result (always reads as both full and empty).\n
                FIFOs are flushed when this bit is changed.

fields.name: fjoin_tx
fields.doc:
When 1, TX FIFO steals the RX FIFO's storage, and becomes twice as deep.\n
                RX FIFO is disabled as a result (always reads as both full and empty).\n
                FIFOs are flushed when this bit is changed.

fields.name: pull_thresh
fields.doc:
Number of bits shifted out of TXSR before autopull or conditional pull.\n
                Write 0 for value of 32.

fields.name: push_thresh
fields.doc:
Number of bits shifted into RXSR before autopush or conditional push.\n
                Write 0 for value of 32.

fields.name: out_shiftdir
fields.doc: 1 = shift out of output shift register to right. 0 = to left.

fields.name: in_shiftdir
fields.doc: 1 = shift input shift register to right (data enters from left). 0 = to left.

fields.name: autopull
fields.doc: Pull automatically when the output shift register is emptied

fields.name: autopush
fields.doc: Push automatically when the input shift register is filled

pio0.sm0_shiftctrl.name: sm0_shiftctrl
pio0.sm0_shiftctrl.doc: Control behaviour of the input/output shift registers for state machine 0

pio0.sm0_addr.name: sm0_addr
pio0.sm0_addr.doc: Current instruction address of state machine 0

pio0.sm0_instr.name: sm0_instr
pio0.sm0_instr.doc:
Instruction currently being executed by state machine 0\n
            Write to execute an instruction immediately (including jumps) and then resume execution.

fields.name: sideset_count
fields.doc: The number of delay bits co-opted for side-set. Inclusive of the enable bit, if present.

fields.name: set_count
fields.doc: The number of pins asserted by a SET. Max of 5

fields.name: out_count
fields.doc: The number of pins asserted by an OUT. Value of 0 -> 32 pins

fields.name: in_base
fields.doc: The virtual pin corresponding to IN bit 0

fields.name: sideset_base
fields.doc: The virtual pin corresponding to delay field bit 0

fields.name: set_base
fields.doc: The virtual pin corresponding to SET bit 0

fields.name: out_base

pio0.sm3_shiftctrl.name: sm3_shiftctrl
pio0.sm3_shiftctrl.doc: Control behaviour of the input/output shift registers for state machine 3

pio0.sm3_addr.name: sm3_addr
pio0.sm3_addr.doc: Current instruction address of state machine 3

pio0.sm3_instr.name: sm3_instr
pio0.sm3_instr.doc:
Instruction currently being executed by state machine 3\n
            Write to execute an instruction immediately (including jumps) and then resume execution.

fields.name: sideset_count
fields.doc: The number of delay bits co-opted for side-set. Inclusive of the enable bit, if present.

fields.name: set_count
fields.doc: The number of pins asserted by a SET. Max of 5

fields.name: out_count
fields.doc: The number of pins asserted by an OUT. Value of 0 -> 32 pins

fields.name: in_base
fields.doc: The virtual pin corresponding to IN bit 0

fields.name: sideset_base
fields.doc: The virtual pin corresponding to delay field bit 0

fields.name: set_base
fields.doc: The virtual pin corresponding to SET bit 0

fields.name: out_base
fields.doc: The virtual pin corresponding to OUT bit 0

pio0.irq0_ints.name: irq0_ints
pio0.irq0_ints.doc: Interrupt status after masking & forcing for irq0

pio0.irq1_ints.name: irq1_ints
pio0.irq1_ints.doc: Interrupt status after masking & forcing for irq1

sio.name: sio
sio.doc:
Single-cycle IO block\n
        Provides core-local and inter-core hardware for the two processors, with single-cycle access.

sio.cpuid.name: cpuid
sio.cpuid.doc:
Processor core identifier\n
            Value is 0 when read from processor core 0, and 1 when read from processor core 1.

fields.name: gpio_hi_in
fields.doc: Input value on QSPI IO in order 0..5: SCLK, SSn, SD0, SD1, SD2, SD3

fields.name: gpio_out
fields.doc:
Set output level (1/0 -> high/low) for GPIO0...29.\n
                Reading back gives the last value written, NOT the input value from the pins.\n
                If core 0 and core 1 both write to GPIO_OUT simultaneously (or to a SET/CLR/XOR alias),\n
                the result is as though the write from core 0 took place first,\n
                and the write from core 1 was then applied to that intermediate result.

fields.name: gpio_out_set
fields.doc: Perform an atomic bit-set on GPIO_OUT, i.e. `GPIO_OUT |= wdata`

fields.name: gpio_out_clr
fields.doc: Perform an atomic bit-clear on GPIO_OUT, i.e. `GPIO_OUT &= ~wdata`

fields.name: gpio_out_xor
fields.doc: Perform an atomic bitwise XOR on GPIO_OUT, i.e. `GPIO_OUT ^= wdata`

fields.name: gpio_oe
fields.doc:
Set output enable (1/0 -> output/input) for GPIO0...29.\n
                Reading back gives the last value written.\n
                If core 0 and core 1 both write to GPIO_OE simultaneously (or to a SET/CLR/XOR alias),\n
                the result is as though the write from core 0 took place first,\n
                and the write from core 1 was then applied to that intermediate result.

fields.name: gpio_oe_set
fields.doc: Perform an atomic bit-set on GPIO_OE, i.e. `GPIO_OE |= wdata`

fields.name: gpio_oe_clr
fields.doc: Perform an atomic bit-clear on GPIO_OE, i.e. `GPIO_OE &= ~wdata`

fields.name: gpio_oe_xor
fields.doc: Perform an atomic bitwise XOR on GPIO_OE, i.e. `GPIO_OE ^= wdata`

fields.name: gpio_hi_out
fields.doc:
Set output level (1/0 -> high/low) for QSPI IO0...5.\n
                Reading back gives the last value written, NOT the input value from the pins.\n
                If core 0 and core 1 both write to GPIO_HI_OUT simultaneously (or to a SET/CLR/XOR alias),\n
                the result is as though the write from core 0 took place first,\n
                and the write from core 1 was then applied to that intermediate result.

fields.name: gpio_hi_out_set
fields.doc: Perform an atomic bit-set on GPIO_HI_OUT, i.e. `GPIO_HI_OUT |= wdata`

fields.name: gpio_hi_out_clr
fields.doc: Perform an atomic bit-clear on GPIO_HI_OUT, i.e. `GPIO_HI_OUT &= ~wdata`

fields.name: gpio_hi_out_xor
fields.doc: Perform an atomic bitwise XOR on GPIO_HI_OUT, i.e. `GPIO_HI_OUT ^= wdata`

fields.name: gpio_hi_oe
fields.doc:
Set output enable (1/0 -> output/input) for QSPI IO0...5.\n
                Reading back gives the last value written.\n
                If core 0 and core 1 both write to GPIO_HI_OE simultaneously (or to a SET/CLR/XOR alias),\n
                the result is as though the write from core 0 took place first,\n
                and the write from core 1 was then applied to that intermediate result.

fields.name: gpio_hi_oe_set
fields.doc: Perform an atomic bit-set on GPIO_HI_OE, i.e. `GPIO_HI_OE |= wdata`

fields.name: gpio_hi_oe_clr
fields.doc: Perform an atomic bit-clear on GPIO_HI_OE, i.e. `GPIO_HI_OE &= ~wdata`

fields.name: gpio_hi_oe_xor
fields.doc: Perform an atomic bitwise XOR on GPIO_HI_OE, i.e. `GPIO_HI_OE ^= wdata`

fields.name: roe
fields.doc: Sticky flag indicating the RX FIFO was read when empty. This read was ignored by the FIFO.

fields.name: wof
fields.doc: Sticky flag indicating the TX FIFO was written when full. This write was ignored by the FIFO.

fields.name: rdy
fields.doc: Value is 1 if this core's TX FIFO is not full (i.e. if FIFO_WR is ready for more data)

fields.name: vld
fields.doc: Value is 1 if this core's RX FIFO is not empty (i.e. if FIFO_RD is valid)

sio.fifo_st.name: fifo_st
sio.fifo_st.doc:
Status register for inter-core FIFOs (mailboxes).\n
            There is one FIFO in the core 0 -> core 1 direction, and one core 1 -> core 0. Both are 32 bits wide and 8 words deep.\n
            Core 0 can see the read side of the 1->0 FIFO (RX), and the write side of 0->1 FIFO (TX).\n
            Core 1 can see the read side of the 0->1 FIFO (RX), and the write side of 1->0 FIFO (TX).\n
            The SIO IRQ for each core is the logical OR of the VLD, WOF and ROE fields of its FIFO_ST register.

sio.fifo_wr.name: fifo_wr
sio.fifo_wr.doc: Write access to this core's TX FIFO

sio.fifo_rd.name: fifo_rd
sio.fifo_rd.doc: Read access to this core's RX FIFO

sio.spinlock_st.name: spinlock_st
sio.spinlock_st.doc:
Spinlock state\n
            A bitmap containing the state of all 32 spinlocks (1=locked).\n
            Mainly intended for debugging.

sio.div_udividend.name: div_udividend
sio.div_udividend.doc:
Divider unsigned dividend\n
            Write to the DIVIDEND operand of the divider, i.e. the p in `p / q`.\n
            Any operand write starts a new calculation. The results appear in QUOTIENT, REMAINDER.\n
            UDIVIDEND/SDIVIDEND are aliases of the same internal register. The U alias starts an\n
            unsigned calculation, and the S alias starts a signed calculation.

sio.div_udivisor.name: div_udivisor
sio.div_udivisor.doc:
Divider unsigned divisor\n
            Write to the DIVISOR operand of the divider, i.e. the q in `p / q`.\n
            Any operand write starts a new calculation. The results appear in QUOTIENT, REMAINDER.\n
            UDIVIDEND/SDIVIDEND are aliases of the same internal register. The U alias starts an\n
            unsigned calculation, and the S alias starts a signed calculation.

sio.div_sdividend.name: div_sdividend
sio.div_sdividend.doc:
Divider signed dividend\n
            The same as UDIVIDEND, but starts a signed calculation, rather than unsigned.

sio.div_sdivisor.name: div_sdivisor
sio.div_sdivisor.doc:
Divider signed divisor\n
            The same as UDIVISOR, but starts a signed calculation, rather than unsigned.

sio.div_quotient.name: div_quotient
sio.div_quotient.doc:
Divider result quotient\n
            The result of `DIVIDEND / DIVISOR` (division). Contents undefined while CSR_READY is low.\n
            For signed calculations, QUOTIENT is negative when the signs of DIVIDEND and DIVISOR differ.\n
            This register can be written to directly, for context save/restore purposes. This halts any\n
            in-progress calculation and sets the CSR_READY and CSR_DIRTY flags.\n
            Reading from QUOTIENT clears the CSR_DIRTY flag, so should read results in the order\n
            REMAINDER, QUOTIENT if CSR_DIRTY is used.

sio.div_remainder.name: div_remainder
sio.div_remainder.doc:
Divider result remainder\n
            The result of `DIVIDEND % DIVISOR` (modulo). Contents undefined while CSR_READY is low.\n
            For signed calculations, REMAINDER is negative only when DIVIDEND is negative.\n
            This register can be written to directly, for context save/restore purposes. This halts any\n
            in-progress calculation and sets the CSR_READY and CSR_DIRTY flags.

fields.name: dirty
fields.doc:
Changes to 1 when any register is written, and back to 0 when QUOTIENT is read.\n
                Software can use this flag to make save/restore more efficient (skip if not DIRTY).\n
                If the flag is used in this way, it's recommended to either read QUOTIENT only,\n
                or REMAINDER and then QUOTIENT, to prevent data loss on context switch.

fields.name: ready
fields.doc:
Reads as 0 when a calculation is in progress, 1 otherwise.\n
                Writing an operand (xDIVIDEND, xDIVISOR) will immediately start a new calculation, no\n
                matter if one is already in progress.\n
                Writing to a result register will immediately terminate any in-progress calculation\n
                and set the READY and DIRTY flags.

sio.div_csr.name: div_csr
sio.div_csr.doc: Control and status register for divider.

sio.interp0_pop_lane0.name: interp0_pop_lane0
sio.interp0_pop_lane0.doc: Read LANE0 result, and simultaneously write lane results to both accumulators (POP).

sio.interp0_pop_lane1.name: interp0_pop_lane1
sio.interp0_pop_lane1.doc: Read LANE1 result, and simultaneously write lane results to both accumulators (POP).

sio.interp0_pop_full.name: interp0_pop_full
sio.interp0_pop_full.doc: Read FULL result, and simultaneously write lane results to both accumulators (POP).

sio.interp0_peek_lane0.name: interp0_peek_lane0
sio.interp0_peek_lane0.doc: Read LANE0 result, without altering any internal state (PEEK).

sio.interp0_peek_lane1.name: interp0_peek_lane1
sio.interp0_peek_lane1.doc: Read LANE1 result, without altering any internal state (PEEK).

sio.interp0_peek_full.name: interp0_peek_full
sio.interp0_peek_full.doc: Read FULL result, without altering any internal state (PEEK).

fields.name: overf
fields.doc: Set if either OVERF0 or OVERF1 is set.

fields.name: overf1
fields.doc: Indicates if any masked-off MSBs in ACCUM1 are set.

fields.name: overf0
fields.doc: Indicates if any masked-off MSBs in ACCUM0 are set.

fields.name: blend
fields.doc:
Only present on INTERP0 on each core. If BLEND mode is enabled:\n
                - LANE1 result is a linear interpolation between BASE0 and BASE1, controlled\n
                by the 8 LSBs of lane 1 shift and mask value (a fractional number between\n
                0 and 255/256ths)\n
                - LANE0 result does not have BASE0 added (yields only the 8 LSBs of lane 1 shift+mask value)\n
                - FULL result does not have lane 1 shift+mask value added (BASE2 + lane 0 shift+mask)\n
                LANE1 SIGNED flag controls whether the interpolation is signed or unsigned.

fields.name: force_msb
fields.doc:
ORed into bits 29:28 of the lane result presented to the processor on the bus.\n
                No effect on the internal 32-bit datapath. Handy for using a lane to generate sequence\n
                of pointers into flash or SRAM.

fields.name: add_raw
fields.doc: If 1, mask + shift is bypassed for LANE0 result. This does not affect FULL result.

fields.name: cross_result
fields.doc: If 1, feed the opposite lane's result into this lane's accumulator on POP.

fields.name: cross_input
fields.doc:
If 1, feed the opposite lane's accumulator into this lane's shift + mask hardware.\n
                Takes effect even if ADD_RAW is set (the CROSS_INPUT mux is before the shift+mask bypass)

fields.name: signed
fields.doc:
If SIGNED is set, the shifted and masked accumulator value is sign-extended to 32 bits\n
                before adding to BASE0, and LANE0 PEEK/POP appear extended to 32 bits when read by processor.

fields.name: mask_msb
fields.doc:
The most-significant bit allowed to pass by the mask (inclusive)\n
                Setting MSB < LSB may cause chip to turn inside-out

fields.name: mask_lsb
fields.doc: The least-significant bit allowed to pass by the mask (inclusive)

fields.name: shift
fields.doc: Logical right-shift applied to accumulator before masking

fields.name: force_msb
fields.doc:
ORed into bits 29:28 of the lane result presented to the processor on the bus.\n
                No effect on the internal 32-bit datapath. Handy for using a lane to generate sequence\n
                of pointers into flash or SRAM.

fields.name: add_raw
fields.doc: If 1, mask + shift is bypassed for LANE1 result. This does not affect FULL result.

fields.name: cross_result
fields.doc: If 1, feed the opposite lane's result into this lane's accumulator on POP.

fields.name: cross_input
fields.doc:
If 1, feed the opposite lane's accumulator into this lane's shift + mask hardware.\n
                Takes effect even if ADD_RAW is set (the CROSS_INPUT mux is before the shift+mask bypass)

fields.name: signed
fields.doc:
If SIGNED is set, the shifted and masked accumulator value is sign-extended to 32 bits\n
                before adding to BASE1, and LANE1 PEEK/POP appear extended to 32 bits when read by processor.

fields.name: mask_msb
fields.doc:
The most-significant bit allowed to pass by the mask (inclusive)\n
                Setting MSB < LSB may cause chip to turn inside-out

fields.name: mask_lsb
fields.doc: The least-significant bit allowed to pass by the mask (inclusive)

fields.name: shift
fields.doc: Logical right-shift applied to accumulator before masking

sio.interp0_accum0_add.name: interp0_accum0_add
sio.interp0_accum0_add.doc:
Values written here are atomically added to ACCUM0\n
            Reading yields lane 0's raw shift and mask value (BASE0 not added).

sio.interp0_accum1_add.name: interp0_accum1_add
sio.interp0_accum1_add.doc:
Values written here are atomically added to ACCUM1\n
            Reading yields lane 1's raw shift and mask value (BASE1 not added).

sio.interp0_base_1and0.name: interp0_base_1and0
sio.interp0_base_1and0.doc:
On write, the lower 16 bits go to BASE0, upper bits to BASE1 simultaneously.\n
            Each half is sign-extended to 32 bits if that lane's SIGNED flag is set.

sio.interp1_pop_lane0.name: interp1_pop_lane0
sio.interp1_pop_lane0.doc: Read LANE0 result, and simultaneously write lane results to both accumulators (POP).

sio.interp1_pop_lane1.name: interp1_pop_lane1
sio.interp1_pop_lane1.doc: Read LANE1 result, and simultaneously write lane results to both accumulators (POP).

sio.interp1_pop_full.name: interp1_pop_full
sio.interp1_pop_full.doc: Read FULL result, and simultaneously write lane results to both accumulators (POP).

sio.interp1_peek_lane0.name: interp1_peek_lane0
sio.interp1_peek_lane0.doc: Read LANE0 result, without altering any internal state (PEEK).

sio.interp1_peek_lane1.name: interp1_peek_lane1
sio.interp1_peek_lane1.doc: Read LANE1 result, without altering any internal state (PEEK).

sio.interp1_peek_full.name: interp1_peek_full
sio.interp1_peek_full.doc: Read FULL result, without altering any internal state (PEEK).

fields.name: overf1
fields.doc: Indicates if any masked-off MSBs in ACCUM1 are set.

fields.name: overf0

fields.name: clamp
fields.doc:
Only present on INTERP1 on each core. If CLAMP mode is enabled:\n
                - LANE0 result is shifted and masked ACCUM0, clamped by a lower bound of\n

                - Signedness of these comparisons is determined by LANE0_CTRL_SIGNED

sio.spinlock0.name: spinlock0
sio.spinlock0.doc:
Reading from a spinlock address will:

            - Return 0 if lock is already locked

            - Otherwise return nonzero, and simultaneously claim the lock


            Writing (any value) releases the lock.

            If core 0 and core 1 attempt to claim the same lock simultaneously, core 0 wins.

            The value returned on success is 0x1 << lock number.

Reading from a spinlock address will:

            - Return 0 if lock is already locked

            - Otherwise return nonzero, and simultaneously claim the lock


            Writing (any value) releases the lock.

            If core 0 and core 1 attempt to claim the same lock simultaneously, core 0 wins.

            The value returned on success is 0x1 << lock number.

sio.spinlock19.doc:

            - Return 0 if lock is already locked

            - Otherwise return nonzero, and simultaneously claim the lock


            Writing (any value) releases the lock.

            If core 0 and core 1 attempt to claim the same lock simultaneously, core 0 wins.

            The value returned on success is 0x1 << lock number.

fields.name: countflag
fields.doc: Returns 1 if timer counted to 0 since last time this was read. Clears on read by application or debugger.

fields.name: clksource
fields.doc:
SysTick clock source. Always reads as one if SYST_CALIB reports NOREF.\n
                Selects the SysTick timer clock source:\n
                0 = External reference clock.\n
                1 = Processor clock.

fields.name: tickint
fields.doc:
Enables SysTick exception request:\n
                0 = Counting down to zero does not assert the SysTick exception request.\n
                1 = Counting down to zero to asserts the SysTick exception request.

fields.name: enable
fields.doc:
Enable SysTick counter:\n
                0 = Counter disabled.\n
                1 = Counter enabled.

ppb.syst_csr.name: syst_csr
ppb.syst_csr.doc: Use the SysTick Control and Status Register to enable the SysTick features.

fields.name: reload
fields.doc: Value to load into the SysTick Current Value Register when the counter reaches 0.

ppb.syst_rvr.name: syst_rvr
ppb.syst_rvr.doc:
Use the SysTick Reload Value Register to specify the start value to load into the current value register when the counter reaches 0. It can be any value between 0 and 0x00FFFFFF. A start value of 0 is possible, but has no effect because the SysTick interrupt and COUNTFLAG are activated when counting from 1 to 0. The reset value of this register is UNKNOWN.\n
            To generate a multi-shot timer with a period of N processor clock cycles, use a RELOAD value of N-1. For example, if the SysTick interrupt is required every 100 clock pulses, set RELOAD to 99.

fields.name: current
fields.doc: Reads return the current value of the SysTick counter. This register is write-clear. Writing to it with any value clears the register to 0. Clearing this register also clears the COUNTFLAG bit of the SysTick Control and Status Register.

ppb.syst_cvr.name: syst_cvr
ppb.syst_cvr.doc: Use the SysTick Current Value Register to find the current value in the register. The reset value of this register is UNKNOWN.

fields.name: noref
fields.doc: If reads as 1, the Reference clock is not provided - the CLKSOURCE bit of the SysTick Control and Status register will be forced to 1 and cannot be cleared to 0.

fields.name: skew
fields.doc: If reads as 1, the calibration value for 10ms is inexact (due to clock frequency).

fields.name: tenms
fields.doc: An optional Reload value to be used for 10ms (100Hz) timing, subject to system clock skew errors. If the value reads as 0, the calibration value is not known.

ppb.syst_calib.name: syst_calib
ppb.syst_calib.doc: Use the SysTick Calibration Value Register to enable software to scale to any required speed using divide and multiply.

fields.name: setena
fields.doc:
Interrupt set-enable bits.\n
                Write:\n
                0 = No effect.\n
                1 = Enable interrupt.\n
                Read:\n
                0 = Interrupt disabled.\n
                1 = Interrupt enabled.

ppb.nvic_iser.name: nvic_iser
ppb.nvic_iser.doc:
Use the Interrupt Set-Enable Register to enable interrupts and determine which interrupts are currently enabled.\n
            If a pending interrupt is enabled, the NVIC activates the interrupt based on its priority. If an interrupt is not enabled, asserting its interrupt signal changes the interrupt state to pending, but the NVIC never activates the interrupt, regardless of its priority.

fields.name: clrena
fields.doc:
Interrupt clear-enable bits.\n
                Write:\n
                0 = No effect.\n
                1 = Disable interrupt.\n
                Read:\n
                0 = Interrupt disabled.\n
                1 = Interrupt enabled.

ppb.nvic_icer.name: nvic_icer
ppb.nvic_icer.doc: Use the Interrupt Clear-Enable Registers to disable interrupts and determine which interrupts are currently enabled.

fields.name: setpend
fields.doc:
Interrupt set-pending bits.\n
                Write:\n
                0 = No effect.\n
                1 = Changes interrupt state to pending.\n
                Read:\n
                0 = Interrupt is not pending.\n
                1 = Interrupt is pending.\n
                Note: Writing 1 to the NVIC_ISPR bit corresponding to:\n
                An interrupt that is pending has no effect.\n
                A disabled interrupt sets the state of that interrupt to pending.

ppb.nvic_ispr.name: nvic_ispr
ppb.nvic_ispr.doc: The NVIC_ISPR forces interrupts into the pending state, and shows which interrupts are pending.

fields.name: clrpend
fields.doc:
Interrupt clear-pending bits.\n
                Write:\n
                0 = No effect.\n
                1 = Removes pending state and interrupt.\n
                Read:\n
                0 = Interrupt is not pending.\n
                1 = Interrupt is pending.

ppb.nvic_icpr.name: nvic_icpr
ppb.nvic_icpr.doc: Use the Interrupt Clear-Pending Register to clear pending interrupts and determine which interrupts are currently pending.

ppb.nvic_ipr0.name: nvic_ipr0
ppb.nvic_ipr0.doc:
Use the Interrupt Priority Registers to assign a priority from 0 to 3 to each of the available interrupts. 0 is the highest priority, and 3 is the lowest.\n
            Note: Writing 1 to an NVIC_ICPR bit does not affect the active state of the corresponding interrupt.\n
            These registers are only word-accessible

ppb.nvic_ipr1.name: nvic_ipr1
ppb.nvic_ipr1.doc: Use the Interrupt Priority Registers to assign a priority from 0 to 3 to each of the available interrupts. 0 is the highest priority, and 3 is the lowest.

ppb.nvic_ipr2.name: nvic_ipr2
ppb.nvic_ipr2.doc: Use the Interrupt Priority Registers to assign a priority from 0 to 3 to each of the available interrupts. 0 is the highest priority, and 3 is the lowest.

ppb.nvic_ipr3.name: nvic_ipr3
ppb.nvic_ipr3.doc: Use the Interrupt Priority Registers to assign a priority from 0 to 3 to each of the available interrupts. 0 is the highest priority, and 3 is the lowest.

ppb.nvic_ipr4.name: nvic_ipr4
ppb.nvic_ipr4.doc: Use the Interrupt Priority Registers to assign a priority from 0 to 3 to each of the available interrupts. 0 is the highest priority, and 3 is the lowest.

ppb.nvic_ipr5.name: nvic_ipr5
ppb.nvic_ipr5.doc: Use the Interrupt Priority Registers to assign a priority from 0 to 3 to each of the available interrupts. 0 is the highest priority, and 3 is the lowest.

ppb.nvic_ipr6.name: nvic_ipr6
ppb.nvic_ipr6.doc: Use the Interrupt Priority Registers to assign a priority from 0 to 3 to each of the available interrupts. 0 is the highest priority, and 3 is the lowest.

ppb.nvic_ipr7.name: nvic_ipr7
ppb.nvic_ipr7.doc: Use the Interrupt Priority Registers to assign a priority from 0 to 3 to each of the available interrupts. 0 is the highest priority, and 3 is the lowest.

fields.name: variant
fields.doc:
Major revision number n in the rnpm revision status:\n
                0x0 = Revision 0.

fields.name: architecture
fields.doc:
Constant that defines the architecture of the processor:\n
                0xC = ARMv6-M architecture.

fields.name: partno
fields.doc: Number of processor within family: 0xC60 = Cortex-M0+

fields.name: revision
fields.doc:
Minor revision number m in the rnpm revision status:\n
                0x1 = Patch 1.

ppb.cpuid.name: cpuid
ppb.cpuid.doc: Read the CPU ID Base Register to determine: the ID number of the processor core, the version number of the processor core, the implementation details of the processor core.

fields.name: nmipendset
fields.doc:
Setting this bit will activate an NMI. Since NMI is the highest priority exception, it will activate as soon as it is registered.\n
                NMI set-pending bit.\n
                Write:\n
                0 = No effect.\n
                1 = Changes NMI exception state to pending.\n
                Read:\n
                0 = NMI exception is not pending.\n
                1 = NMI exception is pending.\n
                Because NMI is the highest-priority exception, normally the processor enters the NMI\n
                exception handler as soon as it detects a write of 1 to this bit. Entering the handler then clears\n
                this bit to 0. This means a read of this bit by the NMI exception handler returns 1 only if the\n
                NMI signal is reasserted while the processor is executing that handler.

fields.name: pendsvset
fields.doc:
PendSV set-pending bit.\n
                Write:\n
                0 = No effect.\n
                1 = Changes PendSV exception state to pending.\n
                Read:\n
                0 = PendSV exception is not pending.\n
                1 = PendSV exception is pending.\n
                Writing 1 to this bit is the only way to set the PendSV exception state to pending.

fields.name: pendsvclr
fields.doc:
PendSV clear-pending bit.\n
                Write:\n
                0 = No effect.\n
                1 = Removes the pending state from the PendSV exception.

fields.name: pendstset
fields.doc:
SysTick exception set-pending bit.\n
                Write:\n
                0 = No effect.\n
                1 = Changes SysTick exception state to pending.\n
                Read:\n
                0 = SysTick exception is not pending.\n
                1 = SysTick exception is pending.

fields.name: pendstclr
fields.doc:
SysTick exception clear-pending bit.\n
                Write:\n
                0 = No effect.\n
                1 = Removes the pending state from the SysTick exception.\n
                This bit is WO. On a register read its value is Unknown.

fields.name: isrpreempt
fields.doc: The system can only access this bit when the core is halted. It indicates that a pending interrupt is to be taken in the next running cycle. If C_MASKINTS is clear in the Debug Halting Control and Status Register, the interrupt is serviced.

fields.name: vectpending
fields.doc: Indicates the exception number for the highest priority pending exception: 0 = no pending exceptions. Non zero = The pending state includes the effect of memory-mapped enable and mask registers. It does not include the PRIMASK special-purpose register qualifier.

fields.name: vectactive
fields.doc: Active exception number field. Reset clears the VECTACTIVE field.

ppb.icsr.name: icsr
ppb.icsr.doc: Use the Interrupt Control State Register to set a pending Non-Maskable Interrupt (NMI), set or clear a pending PendSV, set or clear a pending SysTick, check for pending exceptions, check the vector number of the highest priority pended exception, check the vector number of the active exception.

fields.name: tbloff
fields.doc: Bits [31:8] of the indicate the vector table offset address.

ppb.vtor.name: vtor
ppb.vtor.doc: The VTOR holds the vector table offset address.

fields.name: vectkey
fields.doc:
Register key:\n
                Reads as Unknown\n
                On writes, write 0x05FA to VECTKEY, otherwise the write is ignored.

fields.name: sysresetreq
fields.doc: Writing 1 to this bit causes the SYSRESETREQ signal to the outer system to be asserted to request a reset. The intention is to force a large system reset of all major components except for debug. The C_HALT bit in the DHCSR is cleared as a result of the system reset requested. The debugger does not lose contact with the device.

fields.name: vectclractive
fields.doc: Clears all active state information for fixed and configurable exceptions. This bit: is self-clearing, can only be set by the DAP when the core is halted.  When set: clears all active exception status of the processor, forces a return to Thread mode, forces an IPSR of 0. A debugger must re-initialize the stack.

ppb.aircr.name: aircr
ppb.aircr.doc: Use the Application Interrupt and Reset Control Register to: determine data endianness, clear all active state information from debug halt mode, request a system reset.

fields.name: sevonpend
fields.doc:
Send Event on Pending bit:\n
                0 = Only enabled interrupts or events can wakeup the processor, disabled interrupts are excluded.\n
                1 = Enabled events and all interrupts, including disabled interrupts, can wakeup the processor.\n
                When an event or interrupt becomes pending, the event signal wakes up the processor from WFE. If the\n
                processor is not waiting for an event, the event is registered and affects the next WFE.\n
                The processor also wakes up on execution of an SEV instruction or an external event.

fields.name: sleepdeep
fields.doc:
Controls whether the processor uses sleep or deep sleep as its low power mode:\n
                0 = Sleep.\n
                1 = Deep sleep.

fields.name: sleeponexit
fields.doc:
Indicates sleep-on-exit when returning from Handler mode to Thread mode:\n
                0 = Do not sleep when returning to Thread mode.\n
                1 = Enter sleep, or deep sleep, on return from an ISR to Thread mode.\n
                Setting this bit to 1 enables an interrupt driven application to avoid returning to an empty main application.

ppb.scr.name: scr
ppb.scr.doc: System Control Register. Use the System Control Register for power-management functions: signal to the system when the processor can enter a low power state, control how the processor enters and exits low power states.

fields.name: stkalign
fields.doc: Always reads as one, indicates 8-byte stack alignment on exception entry. On exception entry, the processor uses bit[9] of the stacked PSR to indicate the stack alignment. On return from the exception it uses this stacked bit to restore the correct stack alignment.

fields.name: unalign_trp
fields.doc: Always reads as one, indicates that all unaligned accesses generate a HardFault.

ppb.ccr.name: ccr
ppb.ccr.doc: The Configuration and Control Register permanently enables stack alignment and causes unaligned accesses to result in a Hard Fault.

ppb.shpr2.name: shpr2
ppb.shpr2.doc: System handlers are a special class of exception handler that can have their priority set to any of the priority levels. Use the System Handler Priority Register 2 to set the priority of SVCall.

ppb.shpr3.name: shpr3
ppb.shpr3.doc: System handlers are a special class of exception handler that can have their priority set to any of the priority levels. Use the System Handler Priority Register 3 to set the priority of PendSV and SysTick.

fields.name: svcallpended
fields.doc: Reads as 1 if SVCall is Pending.  Write 1 to set pending SVCall, write 0 to clear pending SVCall.

ppb.shcsr.name: shcsr
ppb.shcsr.doc: Use the System Handler Control and State Register to determine or clear the pending status of SVCall.

fields.name: iregion
fields.doc: Instruction region. Reads as zero as ARMv6-M only supports a unified MPU.

fields.name: dregion
fields.doc: Number of regions supported by the MPU.

fields.name: separate
fields.doc: Indicates support for separate instruction and data address maps. Reads as 0 as ARMv6-M only supports a unified MPU.

ppb.mpu_type.name: mpu_type
ppb.mpu_type.doc: Read the MPU Type Register to determine if the processor implements an MPU, and how many regions the MPU supports.

fields.name: privdefena
fields.doc:
Controls whether the default memory map is enabled as a background region for privileged accesses. This bit is ignored when ENABLE is clear.\n
                0 = If the MPU is enabled, disables use of the default memory map. Any memory access to a location not\n
                covered by any enabled region causes a fault.\n
                1 = If the MPU is enabled, enables use of the default memory map as a background region for privileged software accesses.\n
                When enabled, the background region acts as if it is region number -1. Any region that is defined and enabled has priority over this default map.

fields.name: hfnmiena
fields.doc:
Controls the use of the MPU for HardFaults and NMIs. Setting this bit when ENABLE is clear results in UNPREDICTABLE behaviour.\n
                When the MPU is enabled:\n
                0 = MPU is disabled during HardFault and NMI handlers, regardless of the value of the ENABLE bit.\n
                1 = the MPU is enabled during HardFault and NMI handlers.

fields.name: enable
fields.doc:
Enables the MPU. If the MPU is disabled, privileged and unprivileged accesses use the default memory map.\n
                0 = MPU disabled.\n
                1 = MPU enabled.

ppb.mpu_ctrl.name: mpu_ctrl
ppb.mpu_ctrl.doc: Use the MPU Control Register to enable and disable the MPU, and to control whether the default memory map is enabled as a background region for privileged accesses, and whether the MPU is enabled for HardFaults and NMIs.

fields.name: region
fields.doc:
Indicates the MPU region referenced by the MPU_RBAR and MPU_RASR registers.\n
                The MPU supports 8 memory regions, so the permitted values of this field are 0-7.

ppb.mpu_rnr.name: mpu_rnr
ppb.mpu_rnr.doc: Use the MPU Region Number Register to select the region currently accessed by MPU_RBAR and MPU_RASR.

fields.name: valid
fields.doc:
On writes, indicates whether the write must update the base address of the region identified by the REGION field, updating the MPU_RNR to indicate this new region.\n
                Write:\n
                0 = MPU_RNR not changed, and the processor:\n
                Updates the base address for the region specified in the MPU_RNR.\n
                Ignores the value of the REGION field.\n
                1 = The processor:\n
                Updates the value of the MPU_RNR to the value of the REGION field.\n
                Updates the base address for the region specified in the REGION field.\n
                Always reads as zero.

fields.name: region
fields.doc: On writes, specifies the number of the region whose base address to update provided VALID is set written as 1. On reads, returns bits [3:0] of MPU_RNR.

ppb.mpu_rbar.name: mpu_rbar
ppb.mpu_rbar.doc: Read the MPU Region Base Address Register to determine the base address of the region identified by MPU_RNR. Write to update the base address of said region or that of a specified region, with whose number MPU_RNR will also be updated.

fields.name: attrs
fields.doc:
The MPU Region Attribute field. Use to define the region attribute control.\n
                28 = XN: Instruction access disable bit:\n
                0 = Instruction fetches enabled.\n
                1 = Instruction fetches disabled.\n
                26:24 = AP: Access permission field\n
                18 = S: Shareable bit\n
                17 = C: Cacheable bit\n
                16 = B: Bufferable bit

fields.name: srd
fields.doc: Subregion Disable. For regions of 256 bytes or larger, each bit of this field controls whether one of the eight equal subregions is enabled.

fields.name: size
fields.doc: Indicates the region size. Region size in bytes = 2^(SIZE+1). The minimum permitted value is 7 (b00111) = 256Bytes

ppb.mpu_rasr.name: mpu_rasr
ppb.mpu_rasr.doc: Use the MPU Region Attribute and Size Register to define the size, access behaviour and memory type of the region identified by MPU_RNR, and enable that region.
